Orga's can add a Season in orga/seasons/new, including starting and closing dates for applications, the coding summer, etc
But in the code, the dates are hardcoded, AND will always override the input from the new-form (AFAIK).
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 Orga) (2 's)) (2 (2 can) (2 (3 add) (2 (2 (1 (2 (2 a) (2 Season)) (2 (2 in) (2 orga/seasons/new))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 including) (2 (2 (2 (2 starting) (2 and)) (2 closing)) (2 (2 dates) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 applications) (2 ,)) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 coding) (2 summer)))) (2 ,)) (2 etc)))))))))) (2 But)) (2 (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 code))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 dates)) (1 (2 are) (2 hardcoded)))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 AND) (2 (2 (2 (2 will) (2 always)) (2 (2 (2 override) (2 (2 the) (2 input))) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 new-form)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 AFAIK) (2 -RRB-))))))) (2 .)))))

it appears that lists that are entered in the "project description" or "issues, features, milestones" fields don't render with bullet points in the project "show" view.

What I usually do in that case is just define the minimal required model class inside the migration.
(1 (2 (2 What) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 usually) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 in)) (2 (2 (2 that) (2 case)) (2 (2 is) (2 just))))))) (1 (1 (2 define) (1 (1 (2 the) (1 (2 minimal) (1 (2 required) (2 (2 model) (2 class))))) (2 (2 inside) (2 (2 the) (2 migration))))) (2 .)))
That way you can still use ActiveRecord in the migration without running the risk of the class not being there at some point down the line.
(2 (2 (2 That) (2 way)) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 (2 can) (2 still)) (2 (2 (2 use) (2 (2 ActiveRecord) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 migration))))) (2 (2 without) (2 (2 (2 (2 running) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 risk)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 the) (2 class)))) (2 (1 not) (2 (2 being) (2 there))))) (2 (2 at) (2 (2 some) (2 point)))) (2 (2 down) (2 (2 the) (2 line))))))) (2 .))))
It also does not add a lot of complexity since usually its just an empty Subclass of ActiveRecord::Base with maybe one belongs_to statement (whatever you need to do the migration).
(2 (2 It) (1 (2 also) (1 (1 (2 (2 does) (1 not)) (1 (2 (3 add) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 lot)) (2 (2 of) (2 complexity)))) (1 (2 (2 since) (2 usually)) (1 (2 (2 (2 its) (1 (2 (2 just) (2 (2 an) (2 (1 empty) (2 Subclass)))) (2 (2 of) (2 ActiveRecord)))) (2 :)) (1 (2 :) (1 (2 Base) (1 (2 with) (1 (1 (2 maybe) (1 (2 one) (2 (2 belongs_to) (2 statement)))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 whatever) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 need) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 do) (2 (2 the) (2 migration))))))) (2 -RRB-))))))))))) (2 .))))

block-code.

From a UX point of view, it would make sense to also have the accept/reject buttons in the single project view.

- [ ]  I understand and can explain the difference between data types (strings, booleans, integers) {inline-code}

- [ ] I am comfortable solving a merge conflict in git {inline-code}
### 2015's examples
#### Skill 1
- I understand and can explain the difference between data types (strings, booleans, integers)
- I have heard of the MVC (Model View Controller) pattern
- I am comfortable creating and deleting files from the command line
#### Skill 2
-    I am confident writing a simple method in ruby
-    I am familiar with the concept of TDD and can explain what it stands for
-    I am able to write a counter that loops through numbers (e.g. from one to ten)
#### Skill 3
-    I am comfortable solving a merge conflict in git.

-    I feel confident explaining the components of MVC (and their roles)

a team of two students apply with min.

two projects (they cannot apply without) which is/are selected from a dropdown list (removing "human" errors related to not spelling project name properly, etc.) — I think that the mentor who is attached to each selected project (we have a name and a github handle) should be added to the team and get an email about it.

As an alternative, a team could be valid (to apply) without a mentor (because we have a validation on project anyway so they can't apply without a project; last year the process was different and the mentor in the team ensured we knew which project each team was attached to), and we pull the mentor information into the team when the team is officially selected.

a session cookie expires when you close the browser.

adding the inline-code converts the inline-code cookie into a real cookie with a expire date in 1 week from now.

it updates the expire date every time you visit the page.

if you visit the page today it will set the expire date to 7 days from now.
(2 (2 (2 if) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 visit) (2 (2 the) (2 page))) (2 today)))) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 (2 will) (2 (2 (2 set) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 expire) (2 date)))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 7) (2 days)) (2 (2 from) (2 now)))))) (2 .))))
if you visit the page again in 2 days from now, it will update the expire date again to 7 days from the page visit.
(2 (2 (2 if) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 (2 visit) (2 (2 the) (2 page))) (2 again)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 2) (2 days)) (2 (2 from) (2 now))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 (2 will) (2 (2 (2 (2 update) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 expire) (2 date)))) (2 again)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 7) (2 days)) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 page) (2 visit)))))))) (2 .)))))
this means if you visit the page every day the cookie will never expire.

AFAIK the GitHub OAuth token has no expiration.
(1 (2 AFAIK) (1 (1 (2 the) (1 (2 GitHub) (2 (2 OAuth) (2 token)))) (2 (2 (2 has) (1 (1 no) (2 expiration))) (2 .))))
this means the OAuth token we get back from GitHub can be used until it's manually revoked by the user.

(2 (2 (2 (2 number) (2 (2 of) (2 students))) (2 (2 to) (2 two))) (2 .))
Editing and deleting roles, etc. are taken into account, the validation process takes place in memory, not relying on data yet to be persisted.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (1 (2 (2 (2 Editing) (2 and)) (2 deleting)) (2 roles)) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 etc.) (2 (2 are) (2 (2 taken) (2 (2 into) (2 account))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 validation) (2 process))) (2 (2 takes) (2 (2 place) (2 (2 in) (2 memory))))) (2 ,)))) (1 not)) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 relying) (2 on)) (2 data)) (2 yet)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 be) (2 persisted))))) (2 .))
ace624f adds the validation for the team model.
(3 (2 ace624f) (3 (3 (2 adds) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 validation)) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 the) (2 (3 team) (2 model)))))) (2 .)))
dda1f8f adds the classic behavior of firing the team's validations when saving a role, which will add the default Rails error message to the role: **inline-code**.
(1 (1 (1 (1 (2 dda1f8f) (1 (2 adds) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 classic) (2 behavior))) (1 (2 of) (1 (1 (2 firing) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (3 team) (2 's))) (2 validations))) (2 (2 when) (2 (2 saving) (2 (1 (2 (2 a) (2 role)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 will) (2 (2 (3 add) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 default) (2 (2 Rails) (1 (1 error) (2 message)))))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 role)))))))))))))) (2 :)) (2 (2 **) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 **)))) (2 .))
I personally don't like this behavior, as I think it doesn't provide meaningful insights to the user.
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 personally) (2 (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 (2 (2 (3 like) (2 (2 this) (2 behavior))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 think) (2 (2 it) (2 (1 (2 does) (2 n't)) (3 (3 (2 provide) (3 (3 meaningful) (3 insights))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 user))))))))))) (2 .))))
It rather adds complexity for her to understand what went wrong (_"2 errors prohibited this role from being saved ... Team is invalid"_).
(2 (2 It) (1 (2 rather) (1 (1 (1 (2 adds) (1 (2 (2 complexity) (2 (2 for) (2 her))) (2 (2 to) (1 (2 understand) (1 (2 what) (1 (2 went) (1 wrong))))))) (0 (2 -LRB-) (2 (1 (2 _) (0 (2 ``) (1 (1 (2 (1 (1 (2 2) (1 errors)) (2 (2 (2 prohibited) (2 (2 this) (2 role))) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 being) (2 saved))))) (2 ...)) (1 (2 Team) (1 (2 is) (2 invalid)))) (2 (2 '') (2 _))))) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 .))))
Therefore 50812f9 undos firing the team model's validations when saving a role and instead displays the team's own error message in the role's form, if adding/editing a role does not suit the constraints of the team the role is connected to.
(1 (2 Therefore) (1 (3 (3 (2 (2 50812f9) (2 undos)) (3 (2 (2 (1 (2 firing) (1 (2 (2 the) (2 (3 team) (2 (2 model) (2 's)))) (2 validations))) (2 (2 when) (1 (2 saving) (2 (2 a) (2 role))))) (2 and)) (3 (2 instead) (3 (2 displays) (3 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (3 team) (2 's))) (2 (2 own) (1 (1 error) (2 message)))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 role) (2 's))) (2 form)))))))) (2 ,)) (1 (1 (2 if) (1 (1 (2 adding/editing) (2 (2 a) (2 role))) (1 (2 (2 does) (1 not)) (1 (2 suit) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 constraints)) (2 (2 of) (3 (2 the) (3 team)))))))) (1 (2 (2 the) (2 role)) (1 (1 (2 is) (2 (2 connected) (2 to))) (2 .))))))
As the **inline-code** button in the team's show view is just a shortcut duplicating the behavior of the normal **inline-code**, the team-context is obvious anyways, so I consider showing the team errors more useful here.

@anikalindtner as far as I remember (however, this conversation is pretty far away, so maybe someone will be able to fill in the blanks) we decided against a "set amount" and for a range, and wanted to change the question to be more general (something along the lines of "how much is needed in your city") because we felt that a) asking for students to break down costs would be too intrusive and b) we had the idea of having the students themselves look up in a calculator the living costs for their own city.

It's a lot easier to keep track of an atomic issue than aggregate ones like this.
(2 (2 It) (2 (2 (2 (2 's) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 lot)) (2 easier))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 keep) (2 (2 track) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 an) (2 (2 atomic) (1 issue)))))) (2 (2 than) (2 (2 (2 aggregate) (2 ones)) (2 (3 like) (2 this))))))) (2 .)))
This said: we are currently a bit swarmed with issues and I'd rather have issues closed that are of no immediate concern than having our issue / feature request list grow over 5+ pages.

Introducing the ID-index, you end up with the same type of params hash, you'd have with normal rails inline-code helpers and nested attributes: an array that gets converted to a hash like (because that's how arrays are passed as params afaik):.

We should restrict adding user as a student if he/she is already added as a coach (confirmed or not confirmed, doesn't matter) in another team.
(2 (2 We) (2 (2 (2 should) (2 (2 (2 restrict) (2 (2 (2 adding) (2 user)) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 a) (2 student))))) (2 (2 if) (1 (2 he/she) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 already)) (1 (1 (2 (2 added) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 a) (2 coach)))) (1 (2 -LRB-) (1 (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 confirmed) (2 or)) (1 not)) (2 confirmed)) (2 ,)) (1 (1 (2 does) (2 n't)) (2 matter))) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 another) (3 team))))))))) (2 .)))

After playing around with the coach / student rules I figured out that currently the system is setup in a way that everyone can get every role as often as they want.
(2 (2 (2 After) (2 (1 (2 playing) (2 around)) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 the) (2 coach))))) (2 (2 /) (2 (2 (2 (2 student) (2 rules)) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 figured) (2 out)) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 currently) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 system)) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 (2 setup) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 a) (2 way))))) (2 (2 that) (1 (2 everyone) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 (2 get) (2 (2 every) (2 role))) (2 (2 (2 as) (2 often)) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 they) (2 want))))))))))))))) (2 .))))
Inclduing that a person can always be additionally added as a student in other teams.
(2 (2 (2 Inclduing) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 person)) (2 (2 (2 can) (2 always)) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 additionally) (2 (2 added) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 student)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 other) (2 teams)))))))))))) (2 .))
But once this person is a student somewhere, that person can't be removed or edited in other teams because the check if the person is a student prevents this.
(1 (2 But) (2 (2 (2 once) (2 (2 (2 this) (2 person)) (1 (2 is) (1 (2 (2 a) (2 student)) (2 somewhere))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 that) (2 person)) (2 (2 (1 (2 ca) (2 n't)) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 removed) (2 or)) (2 edited)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 other) (2 teams)))) (2 (2 because) (2 (2 the) (2 check)))) (2 (2 if) (1 (2 (2 the) (2 person)) (1 (2 is) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 student)) (2 (2 prevents) (2 this))))))))) (2 .))))))
There are now two of ways to fix this:.
(2 (2 There) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 are) (2 now)) (2 (2 two) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 ways) (2 (2 to) (2 (3 fix) (2 this))))))) (2 :)) (2 .)))
* Prevent a Person to be on more than one team in whatever role.
(2 (2 *) (2 (2 (1 (2 Prevent) (2 (2 a) (2 Person))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 (2 (2 more) (2 (2 than) (2 one))) (3 team)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 whatever) (2 role)))))))) (2 .)))
* Prevent a Person to become a student in a team when that person is already added in other teams in whatever role

So this problem is not only limited to coaches, but to everyone who is added as a student and already has a role somewhere.
(1 (2 *) (1 (1 (1 (2 Prevent) (2 (2 a) (2 Person))) (2 (2 to) (1 (1 (1 (2 become) (2 (2 a) (2 student))) (3 (2 in) (3 (2 a) (3 team)))) (2 (2 when) (2 (2 (2 that) (2 person)) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 already)) (2 (2 added) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 other) (2 teams)) (1 (2 (2 in) (2 (2 whatever) (2 role))) (1 (2 So) (1 (1 (2 this) (1 problem)) (2 (1 (1 (1 (1 (2 is) (1 not)) (1 (2 only) (2 limited))) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 to) (2 coaches)) (2 ,)) (2 but)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 everyone) (2 (2 who) (3 (2 is) (2 (2 added) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 a) (2 student)))))))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 already) (1 (2 has) (1 (2 a) (2 (2 role) (2 somewhere)))))))))))))))))) (2 .)))

(2 (2 json) (2 .))
According to a student's bug report, the team coaches were unable to confirm themselves through the UI after being added to a team.
(3 (2 (2 According) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 student) (2 's))) (1 (1 bug) (2 report))))) (3 (2 ,) (3 (2 (2 the) (2 (3 team) (2 coaches))) (3 (2 (2 were) (3 (2 unable) (3 (2 to) (3 (2 (2 (2 confirm) (2 themselves)) (2 (2 through) (2 (2 the) (2 UI)))) (3 (2 after) (3 (2 being) (3 (2 added) (3 (2 to) (3 (2 a) (3 team)))))))))) (2 .)))))
I investigated a little bit, and it seems that this fails for teams whose coaches were added prior to us introducing the "coach confirmation" (meaning, no inline-code was created).

I know this is a stupid quick fix, but the conferences in the teams overview are quite confusing for students — especially if past attendees of conferences belong to a team, as the conferences are not "seasoned" yet — so I'm commenting them out until we find a better way to show them based on the current season (see URL.

I've not removed all of the new user-specific stuff, because we can fall back on forcing a new user to fill out their profile right away if they don't come to the app from a link (rather than end up on the index, which might be a little confusing actually) — but all of the info required for a user to exist is already pulled in from the GitHub profile.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 I) (1 (2 (2 've) (1 not)) (2 (2 (2 (2 removed) (2 (2 all) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 new) (2 (2 user-specific) (2 stuff))))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 because) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 can) (1 (2 (2 fall) (2 back)) (1 (2 on) (1 (1 (1 forcing) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 new) (2 user)))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 fill) (2 out)) (2 (2 their) (2 profile))) (2 (2 (3 right) (2 away)) (2 (2 if) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 (2 (2 come) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 app)))) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 link)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 rather) (2 (2 than) (2 (2 (2 end) (2 up)) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 index)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 might) (2 (2 (2 be) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 little)) (1 confusing))) (2 actually))))))))) (2 -RRB-))))))))))))))))))))) (2 --)) (2 (2 but) (2 (2 (2 all) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 info)) (2 (2 (2 required) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 a) (2 user)))) (2 (2 to) (2 exist)))))) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 already)) (2 (2 pulled) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 GitHub) (2 profile)))))))))) (2 .))

I've not removed all of the new user-specific stuff, because we can fall back on forcing a new user to fill out their profile right away if they don't come to the app from a link (rather than end up on the index, which might be a little confusing actually) — but all of the info required for a user to exist is already pulled in from the GitHub profile.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 I) (1 (2 (2 've) (1 not)) (2 (2 (2 (2 removed) (2 (2 all) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 new) (2 (2 user-specific) (2 stuff))))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 because) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 can) (1 (2 (2 fall) (2 back)) (1 (2 on) (1 (1 (1 forcing) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 new) (2 user)))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 fill) (2 out)) (2 (2 their) (2 profile))) (2 (2 (3 right) (2 away)) (2 (2 if) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 (2 (2 come) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 app)))) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 link)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 rather) (2 (2 than) (2 (2 (2 end) (2 up)) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 index)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 might) (2 (2 (2 be) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 little)) (1 confusing))) (2 actually))))))))) (2 -RRB-))))))))))))))))))))) (2 --)) (2 (2 but) (2 (2 (2 all) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 info)) (2 (2 (2 required) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 a) (2 user)))) (2 (2 to) (2 exist)))))) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 already)) (2 (2 pulled) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 GitHub) (2 profile)))))))))) (2 .))

You don't have to assign inline-code here.
(2 (2 You) (2 (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 assign) (2 inline-code)) (2 here))))) (2 .)))
The default value is inline-code (which is »falsey«).
(2 (2 (2 The) (2 (2 default) (2 value))) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 which) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 '') (2 (2 falsey) (2 ``))))) (2 -RRB-))))) (2 .)))
In fact, forcing the value to inline-code will overwrite the previous value when a conference is edited at a later time.
(2 (2 (2 In) (2 fact)) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (1 (1 forcing) (2 (2 the) (2 value))) (2 (2 to) (2 inline-code))) (2 (2 (2 will) (2 (2 (2 overwrite) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 previous) (2 value)))) (2 (2 when) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 conference)) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 edited) (2 (2 at) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 later) (2 time)))))))))) (2 .)))))

Hi @pratyusha972, we don't want to limit the number of conferences that can be added — we want to limit the number of conferences which attendees can apply to in each conference raffle round.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 Hi) (2 @pratyusha972)) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 (2 want) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 limit) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 number)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 conferences) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 be) (2 added)))))))))))))) (2 --)) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 want) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 limit) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 number)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 conferences) (2 (2 which) (1 (2 attendees) (1 (2 can) (1 (2 (2 apply) (2 to)) (1 (2 in) (1 (2 each) (1 (2 conference) (2 (2 raffle) (2 round))))))))))))))))) (2 .))

Hey @carpodaster ,I have put a condition check on number of conferences limiting it to a maximum number of 3.

display_individual_conference
- [ ] In the display page for a single conference, the information is shown in an uneven format in cases such as when a field is left blank by a user that made the conference resulting in 2 fields appearing in the same line.
(1 (1 (2 (2 display_individual_conference) (2 -)) (1 (1 (2 (2 -LSB-) (2 -RSB-)) (2 (2 (2 In) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 display) (2 page))) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 single) (2 conference)))))) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 (2 the) (2 information)) (1 (2 is) (1 (2 shown) (1 (2 in) (1 (1 (2 an) (2 (2 uneven) (2 format))) (2 (2 in) (2 cases)))))))))) (2 (2 such) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 when) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 field)) (2 (1 (2 is) (2 left)) (2 (2 blank) (2 (2 by) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 user)) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 made) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 conference)) (2 (2 resulting) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 2) (2 fields)) (2 (2 appearing) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 same) (2 line))))))))))))))))))))) (2 .))

My proposal for the basics is: 
- Organizers can create/edit/delete entries
- An entry consists of a title, a description text (editable with Markdown), (multiple) file attachments, an extra URL field, a category, a state (draft/ready) and visibility (visible for students/not visible).
(0 (1 (1 (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 My) (2 proposal)) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 the) (2 basics)))) (2 is)) (2 :)) (2 -)) (1 (2 Organizers) (1 (2 can) (2 (2 create/edit/delete) (2 entries))))) (2 -)) (1 (2 (2 An) (2 entry)) (2 (2 (2 consists) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (1 (2 (2 a) (2 title)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 description) (2 text))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 editable) (2 (2 with) (2 Markdown))) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 multiple) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 (2 file) (2 attachments)))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 an) (2 (2 extra) (2 (2 URL) (2 field))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 a) (2 category))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 state) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 draft/ready) (2 -RRB-)))))) (2 and)) (2 visibility)))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 (2 visible) (2 (2 for) (2 students/not))) (2 visible)) (2 -RRB-)))))) (2 .))

There are pros and cons to each possibility, but I would prefer going with either 1.

(2 (2 (2 or) (2 2)) (2 .))
as I feel that:  
- the teams app is the right spot for such information
- a separate repo would be YET AGAIN another place they have to check regularly, which might overwhelm students
- some of the info is not relevant for applicants or "outsiders", so the website just doesn't seem like the right spot for it.

Hey @carpodaster!

Hey @michaelem, from a quick look at your tests (I might be wrong), it seems like you're using the _should_-syntax as opposed to the _expect_-syntax RSpec introduced some time ago and recommends to use.
(1 (2 (2 Hey) (2 (2 (2 (2 @michaelem) (2 ,)) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 quick) (2 look))) (2 (2 at) (2 (2 your) (3 tests)))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 I) (1 (2 might) (1 (2 be) (1 wrong)))) (2 -RRB-))))) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 it) (1 (2 (2 seems) (2 (3 like) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 're) (2 (2 using) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 _)) (2 (2 should) (2 (2 (2 _) (2 (2 -) (2 (2 (2 syntax) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 (2 opposed) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 _)))) (2 (2 expect) (2 _))))) (2 -)))) (2 (2 (2 syntax) (2 RSpec)) (2 (2 (2 (2 introduced) (2 (2 (2 some) (2 time)) (2 ago))) (2 and)) (2 (2 recommends) (2 (2 to) (2 use))))))))))))) (2 .)))))
It's quite easy to switch to this syntax though.
(3 (2 It) (3 (3 (3 (2 's) (2 (2 quite) (2 easy))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 switch) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 this) (2 syntax)))) (2 though)))) (2 .)))
If your browser is not used to it, googling for the syntax tends to bring you to the old docs....
(1 (1 (2 If) (1 (2 (2 your) (2 browser)) (1 (1 (2 is) (1 not)) (2 (2 used) (2 (2 to) (2 it)))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 googling) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 the) (2 syntax)))) (2 (2 (2 (2 tends) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 bring) (2 you)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 old) (3 docs))))))) (2 ...)) (2 .)))))
these are the current ones :see-no-evil_monkey: 

I think using _expect_ is best practice (see here), so more people are used to reading it like this.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 these) (2 (2 are) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 current) (2 ones))) (2 :)) (2 see-no-evil_monkey)))) (2 :)) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 think) (2 (2 using) (2 (2 _) (2 (2 expect) (3 (2 _) (3 (3 (3 (3 (2 is) (3 best)) (2 (2 practice) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 see) (2 here)) (2 -RRB-))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 so) (2 (2 (2 more) (2 people)) (2 (2 are) (2 (2 used) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 reading) (2 it)) (2 (3 like) (2 this)))))))))))))))) (2 .))

Well, they just _encourage_ you to use the expect-syntax, not **force**, since there seem to be some cases where you could prefer it... so maybe that's why there are no deprecation warnings.

This fixes a bug (that was probably not occurring in the app directly) where each time evaluation was called the resulting score would be added to the last score (so after a few calls it would be higher than it should be).

How I understand the current process: 1) we find interesting conferences around the world and in teams' locations; 2) we contact organizers and arrange diversity tickets and lightning talk spots (if possible); 3) we make a list of conferences who accepted our request; 4) we make a conference raffle.
(0 (1 (2 How) (1 (2 I) (1 (2 (2 (2 understand) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 current) (2 process))) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 1) (2 -RRB-)) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 (2 find) (3 (3 interesting) (2 conferences))) (2 (2 (2 (2 around) (2 (2 the) (2 world))) (2 and)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 teams) (2 ')) (2 locations))))))) (2 ;)) (2 (2 (2 2) (2 -RRB-)) (1 (2 we) (2 (2 contact) (2 organizers))))))) (2 and)) (1 (1 (2 arrange) (1 (2 diversity) (2 (2 tickets) (2 (2 and) (2 (2 lightning) (2 (2 talk) (2 spots))))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 if) (2 (2 possible) (2 -RRB-)))))))) (3 (2 ;) (2 (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 3) (2 -RRB-)) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 make) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 list)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 conferences) (2 (2 who) (2 (2 accepted) (2 (2 our) (2 request)))))))))) (2 ;)) (1 (2 (2 4) (2 -RRB-)) (1 (2 we) (1 (2 make) (1 (2 a) (2 (2 conference) (2 raffle))))))) (2 .))))
The reason why I proposed to make an additional field is that there, on the step 1, we might not know about all the interesting conferences, especially local ones.

To answer your question @mkalininait, we do two raffles in the summer, that's why we have "conferences (1st round)" and "conferences (2nd round)".
(1 (1 (2 To) (1 (2 answer) (1 (2 your) (1 (2 question) (2 @mkalininait))))) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 we) (1 (1 (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 do) (2 (2 two) (2 raffles))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 summer)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 's) (2 (2 why) (2 (2 we) (1 (2 (2 have) (2 ``)) (1 (2 conferences) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 1st) (2 round)) (2 -RRB-)))))))))))) (2 '')) (2 and)) (2 ``)) (1 (2 conferences) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 2nd) (2 round)) (2 -RRB-))))) (2 '')) (2 .)))))
This means any conference added to the "1st round" will be visible for the students and will be a conference they can apply to for a free ticket.
(2 (2 This) (2 (2 (2 means) (2 (2 (2 any) (2 conference)) (2 (2 (2 (2 added) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 1st) (2 (2 round) (2 ''))))) (2 (2 will) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 visible) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 the) (2 students))))))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 will) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 conference)) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 (2 apply) (2 to)) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 free) (2 ticket))))))))))))) (2 .)))

When I first suggested that we ask students for local conferences they would like to attend, I saw it more as a "student tells their supervisor about a conference" type of situation, not an extra feature in the teams app, for the simple reason that we don't actually have an exact plan of how this would work, and adding a feature that has been poorly thought-through is imho worse that adding some of the conferences manually into the teams app.

Before having the suggested conference in the list of conferences students can apply to, one of us needs to contact organisers of the conference anyway and have the free ticket approval; so at the end of the day, I don't think having it in a text field in the app or in a list supervisors send us would make much of a difference.

Currently images embedded / referenced to the activity stream ("minilog" feature) that do not use the https protocol scheme cause browsers to display a mixed content warning.
(2 (2 Currently) (1 (1 (2 (2 images) (2 embedded)) (2 (2 /) (2 (2 referenced) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 activity) (2 stream))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 (2 minilog) (2 '')) (3 feature))) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 (2 do) (1 not)) (1 (2 use) (1 (2 the) (1 (2 https) (2 (2 protocol) (2 (2 scheme) (2 cause))))))))))))) (1 (1 (2 browsers) (1 (2 to) (1 (2 display) (2 (2 a) (1 (2 (2 mixed) (3 content)) (1 warning)))))) (2 .))))

A fresh and decluttered PR

Issue #225 
Adds seeds for users, teams and status updates; application-drafts and projects.
(1 (1 (1 (2 A) (1 (2 (2 (2 fresh) (2 and)) (2 decluttered)) (1 (2 PR) (2 Issue)))) (2 (2 #) (2 225))) (1 (1 (2 Adds) (1 (2 (2 (2 seeds) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 users) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 teams) (2 (2 and) (2 (2 status) (2 updates)))))))) (2 ;)) (1 (2 (2 application-drafts) (2 and)) (2 projects)))) (2 .)))
- [x] An unaccepted team
- [x] An accepted team
- [x] An accepted, but voluntary team
- [x]  Teams from last season
- [x] Status updates per team  
- [x] An application draft, unsubmitted
- [x] An application draft, completed
- [x] A proposed project
- [x] An accepted project
- [x] A rejected project

.

Issue #225 
Adds seeds for users, teams and status updates; application-drafts and projects.
(1 (1 (1 (2 A) (1 (2 (2 (2 fresh) (2 and)) (2 decluttered)) (1 (2 PR) (2 Issue)))) (2 (2 #) (2 225))) (1 (1 (2 Adds) (1 (2 (2 (2 seeds) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 users) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 teams) (2 (2 and) (2 (2 status) (2 updates)))))))) (2 ;)) (1 (2 (2 application-drafts) (2 and)) (2 projects)))) (2 .)))
- [x] An unaccepted team
- [x] An accepted team
- [x] An accepted, but voluntary team
- [x]  Teams from last season
- [x] Status updates per team  
- [x] An application draft, unsubmitted
- [x] An application draft, completed
- [x] A proposed project
- [x] An accepted project
- [x] A rejected project

I think what happened is:.
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 (2 think) (2 (2 what) (2 (2 happened) (2 is)))) (2 :)) (2 .)))
- In the season switch, we don't set the dates for real time, but we destroy the current season
- In #486 , we introduce a second season in the seeds, ie last year's season (2015)
  => Now, when switching phases from a fake phase to real time, the season is destroyed , I think we fall back to the remaining season 2015.
(2 (2 -) (2 (1 (1 (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 In) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 season) (2 switch)))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 (2 (2 set) (2 (2 the) (2 dates))) (3 (2 for) (2 (3 real) (2 time)))))))) (2 ,)) (2 but)) (2 (2 we) (1 (2 destroy) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 current) (2 season)))))) (2 -)) (2 (2 (2 In) (2 (2 #) (2 486))) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 we) (1 (2 introduce) (1 (1 (2 a) (2 (2 second) (2 season))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 seeds)) (2 ,)) (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 ie) (2 (2 (2 (2 last) (2 (2 year) (2 's))) (2 season)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 2015) (2 -RRB-))))) (2 (2 (2 =) (2 >)) (2 Now))) (2 ,)) (1 (2 when) (1 (2 (2 switching) (2 phases)) (1 (2 from) (1 (1 (2 a) (2 (2 fake) (2 phase))) (2 (2 to) (2 (3 real) (2 time)))))))))))))))) (2 ,)) (1 (2 (2 the) (2 season)) (1 (2 is) (2 destroyed)))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 think) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 (2 fall) (2 back)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 remaining) (2 (2 season) (2 2015)))))))))) (2 .)))

The concrete name »current« is not a Rails convention, but re-using method names on different classes (when the expected behaviour is the same or at least similar) is a _Ruby_ convention.
(2 (1 (1 (1 (1 (2 (2 The) (2 (2 concrete) (2 (2 name) (2 (2 '') (2 current))))) (1 (2 ``) (1 (1 (2 is) (1 not)) (1 (2 a) (1 (2 Rails) (2 convention)))))) (2 ,)) (2 but)) (1 (1 (1 (1 (2 re-using) (2 (2 method) (2 names))) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 different) (2 classes)))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 when) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 expected) (2 behaviour))) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 same)) (2 or)) (2 (2 at) (1 least)))) (2 similar)))) (2 -RRB-)))) (1 (2 is) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 _) (1 (2 Ruby) (2 (2 _) (2 convention)))))))) (2 .))
Ruby focusses heavily on the idea of _duck typing_ – meaning it doesn't really care _what_ it is as long as it responds to a certain method.
(1 (1 (2 (2 Ruby) (2 focusses)) (2 (2 (2 heavily) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 idea)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 _) (2 duck)))))) (2 (2 (2 (2 typing) (2 _)) (2 --)) (2 (2 meaning) (2 it))))) (1 (1 (1 (1 (2 does) (2 n't)) (2 really)) (2 (2 care) (2 (2 _) (2 (2 what) (2 (2 _) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 (2 as) (2 long))) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 responds) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 certain) (2 method)))))))))))))) (2 .)))

The season switch methods add some complexity to the inline-code class according to CodeClimate.
(2 (2 (2 The) (2 season)) (2 (2 (2 switch) (2 (2 methods) (2 (2 (3 add) (1 (2 (2 some) (2 complexity)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 class)))))) (2 (2 according) (2 (2 to) (2 CodeClimate)))))) (2 .)))
There are three steps:.
(1 (2 There) (1 (1 (1 (2 are) (2 (2 three) (2 steps))) (2 :)) (2 .)))
- [ ] Extract default dates for a newly created season into some form of constant
- [ ] Re-use these constant default values in inline-code (where applicable) and inline-code
- [ ] Move the inline-code and inline-code into a service class

.
(1 (2 -) (1 (1 (1 (2 -LSB-) (2 (2 -RSB-) (2 (2 Extract) (2 (2 default) (2 dates))))) (1 (2 for) (1 (1 (1 (2 a) (1 (2 (2 newly) (2 created)) (2 season))) (2 (2 into) (1 (2 (2 some) (2 form)) (1 (2 of) (1 (1 (2 constant) (1 (2 -) (1 (1 (2 -LSB-) (2 (2 -RSB-) (2 Re-use))) (2 (2 these) (2 (2 constant) (2 default)))))) (2 values)))))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 (1 (1 (2 inline-code) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 where) (2 applicable)) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 and)) (2 inline-code)) (2 -)) (2 -LSB-)))))) (2 (2 (2 -RSB-) (2 (2 (2 Move) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 (2 inline-code) (2 and)) (2 inline-code)))) (1 (2 into) (1 (2 a) (2 (2 service) (2 class)))))) (2 .))))

Using very specific rules can get confusing fairly quickly, so I'm generally of the opinion to try and make a single class work for several sections (e.g. the inline-code and inline-code views in this case).
(2 (2 (2 Using) (2 (2 (2 very) (2 specific)) (2 rules))) (2 (2 (2 can) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 get) (1 confusing)) (2 (2 fairly) (2 quickly))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 so) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 (2 'm) (2 generally)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 the) (2 opinion)))) (2 (2 to) (1 (2 (1 (2 try) (2 and)) (2 make)) (1 (1 (2 a) (1 (2 single) (2 (2 class) (2 work)))) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 several) (2 sections)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 e.g.) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 (2 (2 inline-code) (2 and)) (2 inline-code)) (2 views))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 this) (2 case))))) (2 -RRB-))))))))))))) (2 .)))

I think the reason is for maintaining the styles.
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 think) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 reason)) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 maintaining) (2 (2 the) (2 styles))))))) (2 .)))
Since we have very similar styles for conferences and seasons, it makes the most sense to try and combine them into one general style, so that if we make any changes we can do them in one fell swoop.
(1 (2 (2 Since) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 (2 (2 have) (2 (2 (2 (2 very) (2 similar)) (2 styles)) (2 (2 for) (1 (2 (2 conferences) (2 and)) (2 seasons))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 it) (2 (2 makes) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 most) (2 sense))) (2 (2 to) (2 (1 (1 (1 (2 try) (2 and)) (2 combine)) (2 them)) (2 (2 into) (2 (2 one) (2 (2 general) (2 style))))))))) (2 ,)))) (2 (2 so) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 (2 if) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 make) (2 (2 any) (2 changes))))) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 them)) (2 (2 in) (2 one))))))))))) (1 (2 (2 fell) (2 swoop)) (2 .)))

(1 (2 Furthermore) (1 (2 ,) (1 (1 (1 (2 Having) (1 (2 the) (1 (2 repeated) (2 (2 row) (2 classes))))) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 makes) (2 things)) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 little)) (2 brittle))) (2 --)) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 could) (2 (2 happen) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 'd) (2 (2 forget) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 use) (2 it)))))))))))) (2 .))))

(4 (2 That) (4 (3 (2 's) (3 right)) (2 !)))
Having those repeated row divs isn't fully necessary when we can leave the styling to the concrete tags inside, or the containers.
(2 (1 (2 Having) (2 (2 (2 those) (2 (2 repeated) (2 row))) (2 divs))) (2 (2 (2 (1 (2 is) (2 n't)) (2 (2 fully) (2 necessary))) (2 (2 when) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (1 leave) (2 (2 the) (2 styling))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 concrete) (2 tags))))) (2 inside)) (2 ,)) (2 or)) (2 (2 the) (2 containers))))))) (2 .)))
Generally it makes sense not to create a lot of divs that we can do without, as this also makes the html dom structure harder to read or debug.
(2 (2 Generally) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 (2 makes) (2 (2 sense) (2 (1 not) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 (3 create) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 lot)) (2 (2 of) (2 divs)))) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 do) (2 without)))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 this) (2 (2 also) (1 (0 (1 (2 makes) (1 (2 the) (1 (2 html) (2 (2 dom) (2 structure))))) (2 harder)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 read) (2 or)) (2 debug)))))))))))) (2 .))))

@carpodaster @joneslee85 @lislis @lucaspinto @tbuehlmann 

please note: this means whenever you commit/push to the master branch and tests pass on Travis then Travis will automatically deploy the app

should you not want that, then just push to a branch and/or submit a pull request

:smile:

From a UX pattern/user perspective, the X inside an input field first and foremost removes the entry done by the user, not the result.
(1 (1 (2 From) (1 (2 a) (1 (2 UX) (2 (2 pattern/user) (2 perspective))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 X)) (2 (2 inside) (2 (2 an) (2 (2 input) (2 field))))) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 first) (2 and)) (2 foremost)) (2 (2 removes) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 entry)) (2 (2 done) (2 (2 by) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 user)) (2 ,)) (1 not)) (2 (2 the) (2 result)))))))) (2 .)))))

@carpodaster 
the inline-code where created at first for future-proofing if there might be some changes with github_handle or more params added and also in order to call inline-code in application_draft factory (+ user controller in update action - deleted in last commits).
(1 (1 (2 @carpodaster) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 where) (2 (2 (2 created) (2 (2 at) (2 (2 first) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 future-proofing) (2 (2 if) (2 (2 there) (2 (2 might) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 (2 some) (2 changes)) (2 (2 with) (1 (2 (2 github_handle) (2 or)) (2 (2 more) (2 params)))))))))))))) (2 added))) (2 and)) (2 (2 also) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 order) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 call) (2 inline-code)) (2 (2 in) (2 application_draft)))))))) (2 factory)))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (1 (1 (2 (2 +) (2 (2 user) (2 controller))) (1 (2 (2 in) (2 (2 update) (2 action))) (2 -))) (2 (2 deleted) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 last) (2 commits))))) (2 -RRB-))))) (2 .))

It happened to me recently.
(2 (2 It) (2 (2 (2 (2 happened) (2 (2 to) (2 me))) (2 recently)) (2 .)))
I think what happened was that I created a branch on the previous branch, instead on master.
(1 (2 I) (1 (2 (2 think) (1 (2 what) (1 (2 happened) (1 (2 was) (1 (2 that) (1 (2 I) (1 (1 (2 created) (2 (2 a) (2 branch))) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 on) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 previous) (2 branch)))) (2 ,)) (2 instead)) (2 (2 on) (2 master)))))))))) (2 .)))
And the stupid - but fast - way I solved it: closing the PR, open a new branch on master, copy the changes and push them to a new PR.
(2 (2 (1 (1 (1 (2 And) (1 (2 the) (1 (1 (0 stupid) (2 (2 -) (2 (2 but) (2 (2 fast) (2 -))))) (2 way)))) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 solved) (2 it)))) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 (2 closing) (2 (2 the) (2 PR))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 open) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 new) (2 branch)))) (2 (2 on) (2 master))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 copy) (2 (2 the) (2 changes)))) (2 and)) (2 (2 (2 push) (2 them)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 new) (2 PR)))))))) (2 .))

Hey @katrin-k, about 2) how to avoid it in the future: it's best to always work in branches.
(1 (1 (1 (1 (2 (1 (1 (2 (2 Hey) (2 @katrin)) (2 -)) (2 (2 (2 k) (2 ,)) (2 (2 about) (2 2)))) (2 -RRB-)) (1 (2 how) (1 (2 to) (1 (1 (1 avoid) (2 it)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 future))))))) (2 :)) (3 (2 it) (3 (3 (2 's) (3 best)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 always) (2 (2 work) (2 (2 in) (2 branches)))))))) (2 .))
When you start a new feature, be sure to branch them off the inline-code branch.
(2 (2 (2 When) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 start) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 new) (3 feature)))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 be) (2 (2 sure) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 branch) (2 them)) (1 (1 off) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 branch)))))))) (2 .))))
There are several tweaks to your terminal command prompt that always show you which branch you're in.
(1 (2 There) (2 (1 (2 are) (2 (2 (2 (2 several) (2 tweaks)) (1 (2 to) (1 (2 your) (1 (2 terminal) (2 (2 command) (2 prompt)))))) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 always) (2 (2 (2 show) (2 you)) (2 (2 (2 which) (2 branch)) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 're) (2 in))))))))) (2 .)))
I find that extremely helpful.
(3 (2 I) (3 (3 (2 find) (3 (2 that) (3 (2 extremely) (3 helpful)))) (2 .)))

#### inline-code

New team, new project, new … 
==> Everything that's newly created

#### inline-code

==> Everything that saves sth.

Love it :thumbs_up_sign: 
Regarding the colours: green, red and blue send very strong messages, and from a UX point of view, I don't think it's a good idea to stray from these "primary" colours.
(3 (2 (2 Love) (2 it)) (3 (2 :) (3 (3 (3 thumbs_up_sign) (2 (2 :) (2 (2 (2 (1 (2 (2 Regarding) (1 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 colours)) (2 :)) (1 (2 green) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 (2 red) (2 and)) (2 blue)))))) (2 (2 send) (1 (2 (2 very) (2 strong)) (2 messages)))) (2 ,)) (2 and)) (2 (2 (2 from) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 UX) (2 point))) (2 (2 of) (2 view)))) (2 (2 ,) (3 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (3 (2 think) (3 (2 it) (3 (2 's) (3 (2 a) (3 (3 good) (2 (2 idea) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 stray) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 these) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 primary) (2 (2 '') (2 colours))))))))))))))))))))) (2 .))))
Turquoise or orange don't really have a "universal" meaning, and it could quickly become confusing and messy.
(1 (1 (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 Turquoise) (2 or)) (2 orange)) (2 (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 really)) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 universal) (2 (2 '') (2 meaning)))))))) (2 ,)) (2 and)) (2 (2 it) (1 (2 (2 could) (2 quickly)) (1 (2 become) (1 (2 (1 confusing) (2 and)) (2 messy)))))) (2 .))

@carpodaster @F3PiX PATH_PARENTS is intended to provide a way to prepend a namespace if one subclasses the comments controller (compare here).
(1 (1 (2 @carpodaster) (2 (2 @F3PiX) (2 PATH_PARENTS))) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 (2 intended) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 provide) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 way)) (2 (2 to) (2 (1 (2 prepend) (2 (2 a) (2 namespace))) (2 (2 if) (2 (2 one) (2 (2 subclasses) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 comments) (2 controller)))))))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 compare) (2 here)) (2 -RRB-))))))) (2 .)))
The issue at hand is that we get to the comments controller which redirects back to the object that the comment was created on and that object is an Activity.
(2 (2 (2 (2 The) (1 issue)) (2 (2 at) (2 hand))) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 get) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 comments) (2 controller))) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 (2 (2 redirects) (2 back)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 object)))) (2 (2 (2 (2 that) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 comment)) (2 (2 was) (2 (2 created) (2 on))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 object) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 an) (2 Activity)))))))))))))) (2 .)))
Thus redirect_to redirects to the activity_path(activity).
(2 (2 Thus) (2 (2 redirect_to) (2 (2 (2 redirects) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 activity_path)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 activity) (2 -RRB-)))))) (2 .))))
That we have differnt kinds of activity is nothing that rails knows about.
(1 (1 (2 That) (1 (2 we) (1 (2 have) (1 (2 (2 differnt) (2 kinds)) (2 (2 of) (2 activity)))))) (1 (1 (1 (2 is) (1 nothing)) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 rails) (2 (2 knows) (2 about))))) (2 .)))
So the current fix works because it creates an activity_path, but it would fall apart as soon as we have another commentable to which we want to redirect to within the root namespace.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 So) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 current) (3 fix))) (2 (3 works) (2 (2 because) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 creates) (2 (2 an) (2 activity_path)))))))) (2 ,)) (2 but)) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 would) (2 (2 (2 fall) (2 apart)) (2 (2 (2 as) (2 soon)) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 (2 another) (2 commentable)) (2 (2 (2 to) (2 which)) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 want) (1 (2 to) (1 (2 (2 redirect) (2 to)) (1 (2 within) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 root) (2 namespace)))))))))))))))))) (2 .))
Another possible solution would be to subclass the comments controller and have something like a StatusUpdates::CommentsController?
(2 (2 (2 (2 Another) (2 (2 possible) (3 solution))) (2 (2 would) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 subclass) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 comments) (2 controller)))) (2 and)) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 something) (2 (2 (3 like) (2 (2 a) (2 StatusUpdates))) (2 :))))))))) (2 (2 :) (2 (2 CommentsController) (2 ?))))
This Controller then could live under /status_updates/comments and always redirect to a status update.
(2 (2 (2 This) (2 Controller)) (2 (2 then) (2 (2 (2 could) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 live) (2 (2 under) (2 (2 (2 /) (2 (2 status_updates) (2 /))) (2 comments)))) (2 and)) (2 always)) (2 (2 redirect) (2 (2 to) (3 (2 a) (2 (2 status) (2 update))))))) (2 .))))

I found that  it has to do with the Google analytics script in application.html.slim  .
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 found) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 has) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 do) (1 (2 with) (1 (1 (2 the) (1 (2 Google) (2 (2 analytics) (2 script)))) (2 (2 in) (2 application.html.slim)))))))))) (2 .)))
With this switched off, everything loads under the recommended 200 ms. With the script switched on, even the plain inline-code view needs way over 400 ms. 

Makes sense?

Bootstrap's way to go is wrapping  a navbar (e.g. using inline-code) around a container.
(2 (2 (2 (2 Bootstrap) (2 's)) (2 (2 way) (2 (2 to) (2 go)))) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 (2 wrapping) (2 (2 (2 (2 a) (2 navbar)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 e.g.) (2 (2 using) (2 inline-code))) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 (2 around) (2 (2 a) (2 container)))))) (2 .)))
For the Teams app it's the other way round: a container / row containing a inline-codeelement.
(1 (2 (1 (2 For) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 Teams) (2 app)))) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 's) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 other) (2 (2 way) (2 round))))))) (1 (2 :) (1 (1 (2 (2 a) (2 container)) (1 (2 /) (1 (2 row) (1 (2 containing) (2 (2 a) (2 inline-codeelement)))))) (2 .))))
.

While we can safely assume that most users are viewing the Teams App from a laptop or otherwise bigger screen/device, there are still a couple of glitches with the overall mobile experience that we can't really ignore :face_with_tears_of_joy: 

This is a feeble attempt at collecting several "smaller" issues and bugs currently happening on the Teams app.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 While) (1 (2 we) (1 (1 (2 can) (2 safely)) (1 (2 assume) (1 (2 that) (1 (2 (2 most) (2 users)) (1 (2 are) (1 (1 (2 viewing) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 Teams) (2 App)))) (1 (2 from) (1 (2 a) (1 (1 (2 (2 laptop) (2 or)) (1 (2 otherwise) (2 bigger))) (2 screen/device)))))))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 there) (1 (2 (2 (2 are) (2 still)) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 couple)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 glitches) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 overall) (2 (2 mobile) (2 experience))))))))) (1 (2 that) (1 (2 we) (1 (1 (1 (2 ca) (2 n't)) (2 really)) (1 (1 (1 ignore) (2 :)) (2 face_with_tears_of_joy))))))))) (2 :)) (2 (2 This) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 feeble) (2 attempt))) (1 (2 at) (1 (2 collecting) (1 (1 (1 (2 several) (1 (2 ``) (1 (2 smaller) (1 (2 '') (1 issues))))) (2 and)) (2 (1 bugs) (2 (2 currently) (2 (2 happening) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 Teams) (2 app)))))))))))))) (2 .))
- [x] 1) box for content filter on the activities page is smaller than its content (see screenshot 1)
- [x] 2) Signed in as and sign out link info (top right) is being wrapped onto the next line (see screenshot 2) (note from and for Katrin: try margin-left: auto; and different width on this one)
- [x] 3) the burger menu is a little all over the place: it doesn't always show all links (e.g. Community and Home), is at times hidden behind other elements (e.g. behind the Activity filter box), is transparent or makes it difficult for the links to be clicked because of the transparency.

@carpodaster @ramonh 
I wanted to not interfere much with existing views and partials and not rearrange much, so came up with a way to deal with inline-code button in edit template (it was confusing while on preview tab).
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 ref) (2 (2 (2 (2 #) (2 534)) (2 (2 new) (2 (2 demo) (2 video)))) (2 here))) (2 :)) (2 headphones)) (2 :)) (2 (2 @carpodaster) (2 (2 (2 @ramonh) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 (1 (2 wanted) (2 (2 to) (2 (1 not) (2 (1 (2 (1 (2 (2 interfere) (2 much)) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 existing) (1 (2 (2 views) (2 and)) (2 partials))))) (2 and)) (1 not)) (2 (2 rearrange) (2 much)))))) (2 ,)) (2 so)) (2 (2 (2 (2 came) (2 up)) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 a) (2 way)))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 deal) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 (2 inline-code) (2 button)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 edit) (2 template)))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 it) (2 (2 was) (2 (1 confusing) (2 (2 while) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 preview) (2 tab))))))) (2 -RRB-))))))))) (2 .))))
I've created inline-code with inline-code method that checks if it's inline-code action and displays the button if so.
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 've) (2 (2 (2 created) (2 inline-code)) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 (2 inline-code) (2 method)) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 (2 (2 checks) (2 (2 if) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 's) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 action)))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 displays) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 button)) (2 (2 if) (2 so)))))))))) (2 .)))
What do you think about this?
(2 (2 What) (2 (2 (2 (2 do) (2 you)) (2 (2 think) (2 (2 about) (2 this)))) (2 ?)))

Currently, when you add an address to CC for a mailing, it will enqueue a mailing job for each address, including CC and BCC.
(2 (2 Currently) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 when) (2 (2 you) (2 (3 add) (2 (2 (2 an) (2 address)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 CC) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 a) (2 mailing))))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 it) (1 (1 (2 will) (1 (2 enqueue) (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 mailing) (2 job))) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 each) (2 address)))) (2 ,)) (1 (2 including) (1 (2 (2 CC) (2 and)) (2 BCC)))))) (2 .)))))))

Putting the Gemfile in the .
(2 (2 (2 (2 Putting) (2 (2 the) (2 Gemfile))) (2 (2 in) (2 the))) (2 .))
gitignore file is very bad practice — the Gemfile is the only way a team can track the additions of needed components, libraries, etc..
(0 (4 (1 (1 (2 (2 gitignore) (2 file)) (1 (2 is) (1 (1 (2 very) (1 bad)) (2 practice)))) (2 --)) (3 (2 (2 the) (2 Gemfile)) (3 (2 is) (3 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 only) (2 way))) (3 (3 (2 a) (3 team)) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 track) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 additions)) (2 (2 of) (2 (3 needed) (2 (2 components) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 libraries) (2 ,)) (2 etc.)))))))))))))) (2 .))
.
(2 .)
If the Gemfile is added to .
(2 (2 (2 If) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 Gemfile)) (2 is))) (2 (2 (2 added) (2 to)) (2 .)))
gitignore, anyone working on the project could add any gem they want and need to their own local file, and push changes that "work on their machine" but obviously wouldn't be working on anyone else's, because needed gems (i.e. libraries) are missing.
(1 (2 gitignore) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 (2 anyone) (2 (2 working) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 the) (2 project))))) (1 (1 (2 (2 (2 could) (2 (2 (2 (2 (3 add) (2 (2 (2 any) (2 gem)) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 (2 (2 want) (2 and)) (2 need)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 their) (2 (2 own) (2 (2 local) (2 file))))))))) (2 ,)) (2 and)) (2 (2 push) (2 (2 changes) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 (2 (2 work) (2 on)) (2 (2 their) (2 machine))) (2 '')))))))) (2 but)) (2 (2 obviously) (2 (2 (2 would) (2 n't)) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 working) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 (2 (2 anyone) (2 (2 else) (2 's))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 because) (2 (2 (2 (3 needed) (2 gems)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 i.e.) (2 libraries)) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 (2 are) (2 missing))))))))))) (2 .)))))
If you absolutely need sqlite in your Gemfile (which you shouldn't, because we use postgres, not sqlite) you will have to comment it out any time you push new changes to the project, which is a lesser evil than removing the Gemfile altogether.
(1 (1 (2 If) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 absolutely) (2 (2 need) (2 (2 sqlite) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 your) (2 Gemfile)))))))) (2 (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 which) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 (2 should) (2 n't)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 because) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 use) (2 (2 postgres) (2 (2 ,) (2 (1 not) (2 sqlite)))))))))) (2 -RRB-))) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 will) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 comment) (2 it)) (2 (2 out) (2 (2 (2 any) (2 time)) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 push) (2 (2 new) (2 changes))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 project)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 which) (1 (2 is) (2 (1 (2 a) (1 (2 lesser) (0 evil))) (2 (2 than) (2 (2 (2 removing) (2 (2 the) (2 Gemfile))) (2 altogether)))))))))))))))) (2 .)))))

#571 doesn't assign a role, it merely switches inline-code to a different user record – re-using everything, including roles, that user record had configured before.

I believe that the reasons for presence validations on the dates itself, is only to make our dev life easier, and not per se helping either the user or data integrity.
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 believe) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 reasons)) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 presence) (2 validations)) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 dates)) (2 itself)))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 only) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 make) (1 (2 our) (2 (2 dev) (2 life)))) (2 (2 easier) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 and) (2 (1 not) (1 (2 (2 per) (2 se)) (2 (2 (2 helping) (2 either)) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 user) (1 (2 or) (2 (2 data) (2 integrity))))))))))))))))))) (2 .)))

I deliberately would not put _"framework"_ there, as it gets especially annoying in the JS world where they drop another one every 24hours and I feel forcing people to look at an new DSL for the same concepts all the time just puts additional pressure.
(2 (2 I) (1 (2 deliberately) (1 (1 (2 (2 would) (1 not)) (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 put) (2 (2 _) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 framework) (2 (2 '') (2 _)))))) (2 there)) (2 ,)) (1 (2 as) (1 (1 (1 (2 it) (1 (1 (2 gets) (1 (2 especially) (1 (0 annoying) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 JS) (2 world))))))) (2 (2 where) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 drop) (2 (2 (2 another) (2 one)) (2 (2 every) (2 24hours)))))))) (2 and)) (1 (2 I) (1 (2 feel) (1 (1 (1 (1 forcing) (2 people)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 look) (2 (2 at) (2 (2 (2 an) (2 (2 new) (2 DSL))) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 same) (2 concepts))))))) (2 (2 all) (2 (2 the) (2 time)))))) (1 (2 just) (1 (2 puts) (2 (2 additional) (2 pressure))))))))))) (2 .))))

For the idea about _"adding an acceptance validation"_ @F3PiX: for me, this does not really feel like a **useful** feature for the users / mentors.
(2 (2 (2 For) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 idea)) (2 (2 about) (2 _))) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 (2 (2 adding) (2 (2 (2 an) (2 (2 acceptance) (2 (2 validation) (2 '')))) (2 (2 _) (2 @F3PiX)))) (2 :)) (2 (2 for) (2 me)))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 this) (2 (1 (2 (2 (2 does) (1 not)) (2 really)) (2 (2 feel) (2 (3 like) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 (2 **) (2 (1 (3 useful) (2 (2 **) (3 feature))) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 the) (2 users))))) (2 (2 /) (2 mentors))))))) (2 .)))))
It creates an additional overhead, an additional obstackle on the way to finally submit the form, but does not provide any guarantees that it will impact what the mentors write.
(1 (2 It) (1 (1 (1 (1 (1 (1 (2 creates) (1 (1 (1 (2 an) (2 (2 additional) (2 overhead))) (2 ,)) (2 (1 (2 an) (2 (2 additional) (2 obstackle))) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 the) (2 way)))))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 finally) (2 (2 submit) (2 (2 the) (2 form)))))) (2 ,)) (2 but)) (1 (2 (2 does) (1 not)) (2 (2 (2 provide) (2 (2 any) (2 guarantees))) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 will) (2 (2 impact) (2 (2 what) (3 (2 (2 the) (2 mentors)) (3 write)))))))))) (2 .)))

**@F3PiX said:**
"You can list requirements here, e.g. skill level of a programming language or framework.
(1 (2 (2 (2 (2 **) (2 (2 @F3PiX) (2 said))) (2 :)) (1 (2 **) (1 (2 (2 ``) (2 You)) (1 (2 can) (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 list) (2 requirements)) (2 here)) (2 ,)) (2 (1 (2 e.g.) (2 (2 skill) (2 level))) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 programming) (2 (2 (2 language) (2 or)) (2 framework))))))))))) (2 .))

Emails are sent to each address separately - no matter if in "to", "cc" or "bcc".
(2 (2 Emails) (2 (2 (2 are) (2 (2 (2 (2 sent) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 each) (2 address)) (2 separately)))) (2 -)) (2 (2 (2 (2 (1 (1 no) (2 matter)) (2 if)) (2 (2 (2 (2 in) (2 ``)) (2 to)) (2 ''))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 cc) (2 (2 '') (2 (2 or) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 bcc) (2 '')))))))))) (2 .)))
Including cc and bcc in each email caused multiple emails to these addresses.
(1 (2 (2 Including) (2 (2 (2 (2 cc) (2 and)) (2 bcc)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 each) (2 email))))) (2 (1 (2 caused) (2 (2 (2 multiple) (2 emails)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 these) (2 addresses))))) (2 .)))
Removing the cc and bcc from each mail solves this.

The thought behind it: most organisers don't really keep track of which hidden "features" are found in the dashboard controller, and since there is no menu for this anywhere, it becomes tedious to remember the URLs or look it up in the inline-code every time.

I haven't done fontend code in a while @F3PiX, so just some thoughts I have when looking at this PR, eventually not really relevant :see-no-evil_monkey: 

So first, I think it's weird, that this piece of code is **always** evaluated completely, even if the client does not show the respective form (80% of all cases I think).

The first line inline-codeIt is a shortcut to bind a function to jQuery's inline-code event from what I remember.
(1 (1 (2 The) (1 (2 first) (2 (2 line) (2 inline-codeIt)))) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 shortcut) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 bind) (2 (2 a) (2 function))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 jQuery) (2 's)) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 event))))) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 what) (2 (2 I) (2 remember))))))))) (2 .)))
So in this context, it basically means: load this anonymous function on inline-code to have it available later.
(2 (2 So) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 in) (2 (2 this) (2 context))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 basically) (2 means))))) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 load) (2 (2 (2 this) (2 (2 anonymous) (2 function))) (2 (2 on) (2 inline-code)))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 available) (2 later))))))) (2 .)))

@jancborchardt that's a very good point, and I think we can definitely improve that help section to make it more understandable :) The line "If you think something is unclear or should be improved" pointing to the issue tracker meant to suggest opening an issue along the lines of, "it's not very clear how to sign up for an account" or "I think the help page could be improved" rather than direct questions about the program, however reading it now I'm realising that it could be understood in another way.

Running inline-code, I noticed a warning I had never seen before:.
(1 (2 (2 Running) (2 inline-code)) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 I) (1 (1 (1 (2 noticed) (2 (1 (2 a) (1 warning)) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 had) (1 never)) (2 (2 seen) (2 before)))))) (2 :)) (2 .)))))
block-code.
(2 (2 block-code) (2 .))
The reason for the warning seems to be a mix of two things: inline-code and the inline-code version we're using.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 The) (2 reason)) (2 (2 for) (1 (2 the) (1 warning)))) (2 (2 seems) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 mix)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 two) (2 things)))))))) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 (2 inline-code) (2 and)) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 version)))) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 're) (2 using))))) (2 .))
The issue with inline-code seems to be fixed by not including the gem in the inline-code group - see this issue.
(2 (2 (2 (2 The) (1 issue)) (2 (2 with) (2 inline-code))) (2 (2 (2 seems) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 be) (2 (3 fixed) (2 (2 by) (2 (1 not) (2 (2 (2 including) (2 (2 the) (2 gem))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 group))))))))) (2 -)) (2 (2 see) (2 (2 this) (1 issue)))))) (2 .)))
This was also addressed in inline-code 3.5.2 as you can see here.
(2 (2 This) (2 (2 (2 (2 was) (2 also)) (2 (2 (2 addressed) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 3.5.2)))) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 see) (2 here))))))) (2 .)))
So, this PR does just that - move inline-code out of the inline-code group and bump inline-code to 3.5.2.
(2 (2 So) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 this) (2 PR)) (2 (1 (2 does) (2 (2 just) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 -) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 move) (2 inline-code)) (2 out)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 group))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 bump) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 (2 to) (2 3.5.2))))))))) (2 .)))))

(2 (2 (2 Let) (2 (2 me) (2 (2 know) (2 (2 what) (2 (2 you) (2 think)))))) (2 !))

## How it looks & works

In the public-facing Community page (inline-code), you'll see an orange button for every user in the list, except yourself.
(2 (2 (2 ##) (2 (2 How) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 looks) (2 (2 &) (2 (3 works) (2 (2 In) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 public-facing) (2 (2 Community) (2 page)))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 -RRB-))))))))))) (1 (2 ,) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 'll) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 see) (1 (2 an) (2 (2 orange) (2 button)))) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 every) (2 user)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 list)))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 except) (2 yourself)))) (2 .)))))
!
(2 !)
impersonation

As soon as you hover your mouse over one of these buttons, you get a bootstrap popover with a small explanation.
(1 (1 (2 (2 impersonation) (2 (2 As) (2 soon))) (1 (2 as) (1 (2 you) (1 (1 (2 hover) (2 (2 your) (2 mouse))) (2 (2 over) (2 (2 one) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 these) (2 buttons))))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 (2 get) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 bootstrap) (2 popover)))) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 small) (3 explanation))))) (2 .)))))
(this may be a bit over the top :smiling_face_with_open_mouth_and_cold_sweat: let me know what you think).

Clicking any of these orange buttons will switch your inline-code to be the impersonated user.
(0 (0 (2 Clicking) (2 (2 any) (1 (2 of) (1 (2 these) (2 (2 orange) (2 buttons)))))) (2 (2 (2 will) (2 (2 switch) (2 (2 your) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 impersonated) (2 user))))))))) (2 .)))
I used a gem called pretender that also gives us a inline-code method, which is the original user.
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 used) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 gem)) (2 (2 called) (2 (2 pretender) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 also) (2 (2 (2 gives) (2 us)) (2 (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 method))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 original) (2 user))))))))))))) (2 .)))
This is how clicking the link looks like:.
(1 (2 This) (1 (1 (1 (2 is) (2 (2 how) (3 (2 (2 clicking) (2 (2 the) (2 link))) (3 (2 looks) (3 like))))) (2 :)) (2 .)))
<img width="1183" alt="screen shot 2016-12-10 at 23 45 21" src="URL.

## Some details

### Keeping this out of production

As you'll see in the code, I'm checking for the production environment at the route level and at the view level.
(2 (2 (2 ##) (2 (2 (2 Some) (2 details)) (2 (2 ###) (2 (2 Keeping) (2 (2 this) (2 (2 (2 out) (2 (2 of) (2 production))) (2 (2 As) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 'll) (2 (2 see) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 code))))))))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 'm) (2 (2 checking) (2 (2 (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 production) (2 environment))) (2 (2 at) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 route) (2 level)))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 at) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 view) (2 level))))))) (2 .)))))
Let me know if you feel I should add some controller-level protection, like a guard clause which is what's being used on the Switch Season Phase feature.
(2 (2 (2 Let) (2 (2 me) (2 (2 know) (2 (2 if) (1 (2 you) (1 (2 (2 (2 feel) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 should) (1 (3 add) (1 (2 some) (2 (2 controller-level) (2 protection))))))) (2 ,)) (1 (3 like) (1 (1 (2 a) (2 (2 guard) (2 clause))) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 what) (2 (2 's) (2 (2 being) (2 (2 used) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 Switch) (2 (2 Season) (2 (2 Phase) (3 feature)))))))))))))))))))) (2 .))
### Tests

I wanted to explore testing the route-level production protections and I (eventually) got it working :person_raising_both_hands_in_celebration: .
(1 (1 (1 (2 (2 ###) (2 Tests)) (1 (2 I) (1 (2 wanted) (2 (2 to) (1 (2 explore) (1 (2 testing) (1 (1 (1 (2 the) (1 (2 route-level) (2 (2 production) (2 protections)))) (2 and)) (2 I)))))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 eventually) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 (2 (2 (2 got) (2 it)) (2 (2 (2 (2 working) (2 :)) (2 person_raising_both_hands_in_celebration)) (2 :))) (2 .)))
At the end of it I had a feeling that this may be testing _too deeply_, so if I'm happy to remove/alter if you'd like.
(2 (2 (2 At) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 end)) (2 (2 of) (2 it)))) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 (2 had) (2 (2 a) (2 feeling))) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 that) (2 (2 this) (2 (2 may) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 testing) (2 (2 _) (2 (2 too) (2 (2 deeply) (2 _))))))))) (2 ,)) (2 so)) (2 (2 if) (3 (2 I) (2 (2 'm) (3 (4 happy) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 remove/alter) (2 (2 if) (3 (2 you) (2 (2 'd) (3 like)))))))))))) (2 .))))

## How it looks & works

In the public-facing Community page (inline-code), you'll see an orange button for every user in the list, except yourself.
(2 (2 (2 ##) (2 (2 How) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 looks) (2 (2 &) (2 (3 works) (2 (2 In) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 public-facing) (2 (2 Community) (2 page)))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 -RRB-))))))))))) (1 (2 ,) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 'll) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 see) (1 (2 an) (2 (2 orange) (2 button)))) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 every) (2 user)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 list)))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 except) (2 yourself)))) (2 .)))))

(2 !)
impersonation

Ok, a bit of a crossroads here:.
(3 (3 (3 (3 Ok) (2 ,)) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 bit)) (2 (2 (2 of) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 crossroads) (2 here)))) (2 :)))) (2 .))
I would either

a) remove inline-code from the the public interface, forward the inline-code methods to a private switcher instance transparently and keep calling inline-code on inline-code 

or

b) leave inline-code completely out of the phase switching business by calling the class directly (see comment above).
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 (2 would) (2 either)) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 -RRB-)) (2 (2 (2 remove) (2 inline-code)) (2 (2 (2 (2 from) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 public) (2 interface))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 (2 forward) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 methods)))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 private) (2 (2 switcher) (2 instance))))))) (2 transparently)))) (2 and)) (2 (2 (2 (2 keep) (2 (2 (2 calling) (2 inline-code)) (2 (2 on) (2 inline-code)))) (2 or)) (2 (2 (2 b) (2 -RRB-)) (2 (2 (1 leave) (2 inline-code)) (2 (2 completely) (2 (2 out) (2 (2 of) (2 (1 (2 (2 the) (2 phase)) (2 (2 (2 switching) (2 business)) (2 (2 by) (2 (2 (2 calling) (2 (2 the) (2 class))) (2 directly))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 (2 see) (2 comment)) (2 above)) (2 -RRB-)))))))))))))) (2 .)))
This would also mean moving the phase-switching examples into a separate spec file for inline-code.
(2 (2 This) (2 (2 (2 (2 would) (2 also)) (2 (1 mean) (2 (2 (2 moving) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 phase-switching) (2 examples)))) (2 (2 into) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 separate) (2 (2 spec) (2 file)))) (2 (2 for) (2 inline-code))))))) (2 .)))

There are a few fields in the application form that are a bit too prone to applicants writing long texts, which we wish to avoid.
(1 (2 There) (1 (2 (2 are) (2 (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 few) (2 fields))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 application) (2 form))))) (0 (2 that) (0 (0 (2 are) (3 (2 (2 a) (2 bit)) (2 (2 too) (2 prone)))) (1 (2 to) (1 (2 applicants) (1 (2 writing) (1 (1 (1 (2 long) (2 texts)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 which) (1 (2 we) (2 (2 wish) (1 (2 to) (1 avoid))))))))))))) (2 .)))
A way to solve this would be to set a character limit on those fields.
(1 (2 (2 A) (2 (2 way) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 solve) (2 this))))) (1 (1 (2 would) (1 (2 be) (1 (2 to) (1 (1 (2 set) (1 (2 a) (2 (2 character) (2 limit)))) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 those) (2 fields))))))) (2 .)))
**Implementation**
- The character limit should be set at the view level in the form
- The length should *probably* be validated at the model level as well (that would be inline-code and inline-code)
- Each input field should contain a hint about the number of characters allowed
- *Bonus / nice to have*: character count going down as the user types (i.e. like you have on twitter) 

**The fields that need a character limit are the following:**

"Please tell us a little bit about yourself.

**RGSoC direct outreach:**
 * RGSoC Blog
 * RGSoC Twitter
 * RGSoC Facebook
 * RGSoC Newsletter
 * RGSoC Organisers

**Past participants or 'Partners':**
 * Past RGSoC participants
 * Another diversity initiative outreach
 * Study group / Workshop
 * Conference

**Other channels:**
 * Friends
 * Mass media
 * Other (please specify)
 * [additional text field for other]
.

Right now, the inline-code field is just a text field; having a list of pre-defined answers rather than a free-form field would allow us to have a better overview of how applicants find out about us, which is valuable information.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 Right) (2 now)) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 field))) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 just)) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 text) (2 field))))))) (2 ;)) (2 (2 (2 having) (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 a) (2 list)) (1 (2 of) (2 (2 pre-defined) (2 answers)))) (2 (2 rather) (2 than))) (1 (2 a) (2 (2 free-form) (2 field))))) (2 (2 would) (2 (2 allow) (2 (2 us) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (3 better) (2 overview))) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 how) (2 (2 applicants) (2 (2 (2 find) (2 out)) (2 (2 about) (2 (2 (2 us) (2 ,)) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 valuable) (2 information)))))))))))))))))) (2 .))
**Implementation**
- this list could lead either to something like a dropdown (i.e. only one possible answer) or a list of checkboxes (leading to one or more answers).
(3 (2 **) (2 (2 Implementation) (2 (2 **) (2 (2 -) (2 (2 (2 this) (2 (2 list) (2 (2 could) (2 (2 (2 lead) (2 either)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 something) (2 (3 like) (2 (2 a) (2 dropdown)))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 i.e.) (2 (2 (2 only) (2 one)) (2 (2 possible) (2 answer)))) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 or)) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 list)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 checkboxes) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 leading) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 one) (2 or)) (2 more)) (2 answers)))) (2 -RRB-)))))))))))) (2 .))))))
Maybe the latter is preferable.

The description and hint of this field should be more direct, so a suggested improvement would be to rename to “Please provide examples of your code” and add the following hint: “Links to completed coding challenge provided by the mentor (if present), commits / pull requests on GitHub or other concise examples of your code.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 The) (2 (2 (2 description) (2 and)) (2 hint))) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 this) (2 field)))) (2 (2 should) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 more) (2 direct))))) (2 ,)) (2 so)) (3 (3 (2 a) (3 (2 suggested) (3 improvement))) (2 (2 would) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 rename) (2 (2 (2 to) (2 ``)) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 Please) (2 provide)) (2 (2 examples) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 your) (2 code))))) (2 '')) (2 and)) (2 (2 (2 (3 add) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 following) (2 hint))) (2 :)) (2 ``)) (2 Links))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 completed) (2 (2 coding) (2 challenge))) (2 (2 provided) (2 (2 by) (2 (2 the) (2 mentor))))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 if) (2 present)) (2 -RRB-)))))))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 commits) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 /) (2 (2 pull) (2 requests))) (2 (2 on) (2 GitHub))) (2 or)) (2 (2 (2 other) (2 (2 concise) (2 examples))) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 your) (2 code)))))) (2 .))))
Links to GitHub profiles and repositories won't be considered.”
(1 (1 (2 Links) (2 (2 to) (1 (2 GitHub) (1 (2 (2 profiles) (2 and)) (2 repositories))))) (2 (2 (2 (1 (2 wo) (2 n't)) (2 (2 be) (2 considered))) (2 .)) (2 '')))
Alternatively, the above could be combined into a single label/description of the field, i.e. “Please provide examples of your code: links to completed coding challenge provided by the mentor (if present), commits / pull requests on GitHub or other concise examples of your code.

First of all, in order to be able to use inline-code, the spec needs to be setup as a proper (model) spec.
(2 (2 (2 First) (2 (2 of) (2 all))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 in) (2 (2 order) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 be) (2 (3 able) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 use) (2 inline-code)))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 spec)) (2 (2 (2 needs) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 setup) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 proper) (2 (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 model) (2 -RRB-))) (2 spec))))))))) (2 .)))))))
So start the file with:.
(2 (2 So) (2 (2 (2 (2 start) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 file)) (2 with))) (2 :)) (2 .)))
block-code.
(2 (2 block-code) (2 .))
Once you've done this, the expectation needs to include the inline-code module as well:.
(2 (2 (2 Once) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 've) (2 (2 done) (2 this))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 expectation)) (2 (2 (2 (2 needs) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 include) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 module)))) (2 (2 as) (2 well))))) (2 :)) (2 .)))))
block-code.
(2 (2 block-code) (2 .))
This is necessary because you're out of the inline-code "namespace" in the spec file.
(2 (2 This) (2 (2 (2 (2 is) (2 necessary)) (2 (2 because) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 're) (2 out)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 namespace) (2 ''))))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 spec) (2 file)))))))))) (2 .)))
You could of course go into it by setting this up like this:.
(2 (2 You) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 could) (2 (2 of) (2 course))) (2 (2 (2 go) (2 (2 into) (2 it))) (2 (2 by) (2 (2 (2 (2 setting) (2 this)) (2 up)) (2 (3 like) (2 this)))))) (2 :)) (2 .)))
block-code.
(2 (2 block-code) (2 .))
However, I **strongly** advise not to do it!
(2 (1 However) (3 (2 ,) (3 (2 I) (2 (1 (2 (2 **) (2 (2 strongly) (2 **))) (2 (2 advise) (2 (1 not) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 do) (2 it)))))) (2 !)))))
inline-code is not a module but a class and the inline-code class not set up to be within the inline-code namespace.
(2 (2 inline-code) (2 (2 (2 (1 (2 is) (1 not)) (2 (2 a) (2 module))) (2 (2 but) (2 (2 (1 (2 (2 a) (2 class)) (2 and)) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 class)))) (2 (1 not) (2 (2 (2 set) (2 up)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 within) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 namespace))))))))))) (2 .)))
If it would, it would look like this:.
(2 (2 (2 If) (2 (2 it) (2 would))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 (2 (2 would) (2 (2 look) (2 (3 like) (2 this)))) (2 :)) (2 .)))))
block-code.
(2 (2 block-code) (2 .))

Well, it's a dev-env-only feature... But anyways, Ruby 2.2 introduced GC for symbols (cc @carpodaster), so as long as you don't do a
block-code.
(1 (1 (2 (2 (2 Well) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 's) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 dev-env-only) (3 feature))))))) (2 ...)) (1 (2 But) (1 (2 anyways) (1 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 Ruby) (2 2.2)) (2 (2 introduced) (2 (2 GC) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 (2 symbols) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 cc) (2 @carpodaster)) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 so) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 long) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 (2 do) (2 (2 a) (2 block-code)))))))))))))))))) (2 .))
DoS from converting any strings to symbols should not be a problem.
(1 (2 (2 DoS) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 (2 converting) (2 (2 any) (2 strings))) (2 (2 to) (2 symbols))))) (2 (2 (2 (2 should) (1 not)) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 a) (1 problem)))) (2 .)))
However, if you prefer strings, feel free to switch to them.
(1 (1 However) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 if) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 prefer) (2 strings)))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 feel) (2 (2 free) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 switch) (2 (2 to) (2 them)))))) (2 .))))))
I just proposed symbols because I personally prefer them over strings.

It's a classic.
(2 (2 It) (2 (2 (2 's) (2 (2 a) (2 classic))) (2 .)))
Katrina Owen has given whole talks about refactoring a case statement :v:.
(1 (2 (2 Katrina) (2 Owen)) (2 (2 (2 has) (2 (2 (2 given) (2 (2 whole) (2 talks))) (2 (2 about) (2 (2 refactoring) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 case) (2 statement))) (2 :)) (2 v)) (2 :)))))) (2 .)))
And yes, for public class methods it's effectively the same.
(3 (2 And) (3 (3 yes) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 for) (2 (2 public) (2 (2 class) (2 methods)))) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 (2 (2 's) (2 effectively)) (2 (2 the) (2 same))) (2 .)))))))
However, if you want to have private ones, only using inline-code is not enough, if I recall correctly, there would be some macros like inline-code or some like this...
Therefore when I want to have private methods (basically all of the time) I use inline-code.
(2 (2 (2 (1 (1 However) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 if) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 (2 (2 want) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 private) (2 ones))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 only) (2 (2 using) (2 (2 inline-code) (3 (2 (2 (1 (2 is) (1 not)) (2 enough)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 if) (3 (2 I) (2 (2 recall) (3 correctly))))))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 there) (2 (2 would) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 some) (2 macros)) (2 (3 like) (2 inline-code))) (2 or)) (2 (2 some) (2 (3 like) (2 this))))))))))) (2 ...)) In older Ruby versions, converting arbitrary user input to symbols using inline-code could be exploited as Denial of Service attacks (and in some cases even privilege escalation … if memory serves?)

Although we asked the students not to mention some of the information in certain fields (e.g. location), we still could sometimes tell from the writing where the student comes from (mentions of workshop names, university names etc.)

**Possible solution**  
After the block "Basics" and before the block "Background Information" put a warning, something like: "In your answers below, please don't mention names (geographical features, universities, companies etc.) which can point to your location and introduce bias during the selection process!"

To make it a bit easier for us to process applications we decided to make an improvement over the field "Gender".
(2 (2 (2 To) (2 (2 make) (2 (2 it) (1 (1 (1 (2 (2 a) (2 bit)) (2 easier)) (2 (2 for) (2 us))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 process) (2 applications))))))) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 (2 decided) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 make) (3 (3 (2 an) (3 improvement)) (2 (2 over) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 field) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 Gender) (2 '')))))))))) (2 .))))
We've been thinking a lot about how to implement a new/better “Gender Self-Identification” field so that on the one hand it had some pre-defined options and on the other hand wasn't exclusive for anyone.

Intro: The step of signing in with a github handle creates a new user in the db and currently allows that signed in user to e.g. create a team.
(2 (2 (2 (2 Intro) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 (2 The) (2 step)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 (2 signing) (2 in)) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 github)) (2 (2 handle) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 creates) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 new) (2 user)))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 db)))) (2 and)) (2 currently)) (2 allows)))))))) (3 (2 that) (3 (2 (2 signed) (2 (2 in) (2 user))) (3 (2 to) (3 (2 e.g.) (3 (3 create) (3 (2 a) (3 team))))))))) (2 .))
The idea was to have a two-step process: first step, signing in, just requires the user to accept the oauth via github: this would give a user some sort of “read-only” access for anything that isn't their user profile (i.e. they can edit their user profile, but cannot do anything else like creating teams or applications).
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 The) (2 idea)) (2 (2 was) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 two-step) (2 process))) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 first) (2 step)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 signing) (2 in))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 just) (2 (2 requires) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 user) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 accept) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 oauth)) (2 (2 via) (2 github))))))))))))))) (2 :)) (2 (2 this) (2 (2 would) (2 (2 (3 give) (2 (2 a) (2 user))) (2 (2 (2 (2 some) (2 sort)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 read-only) (2 (2 '') (2 access)))) (2 (2 for) (2 anything))) (2 (2 that) (2 (1 (2 is) (2 n't)) (2 (2 their) (2 (2 user) (2 profile)))))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 i.e.) (2 (2 they) (3 (3 (3 (3 (2 can) (2 (2 edit) (2 (2 their) (2 (2 user) (2 profile))))) (2 ,)) (2 but)) (1 (1 (2 can) (1 not)) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 (2 anything) (2 else))) (2 (3 like) (2 (2 creating) (2 (2 (2 teams) (2 or)) (2 applications))))))))) (2 -RRB-)))))))) (2 .))
Only once the user has confirmed with their email address can they have access to everything else a user should be able to do, like creating teams and so on.
