Hey @carpodaster,

I just came across a few pre Rails5 era and therefore eventually no longer necessary things while looking into #366.
(1 (2 (2 Hey) (2 @carpodaster)) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 I) (1 (1 (1 (1 (2 just) (1 (2 came) (1 (2 across) (1 (2 a) (1 (2 few) (1 (2 pre) (2 (2 Rails5) (2 era)))))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 (2 (2 therefore) (2 eventually)) (2 (2 (2 (1 no) (2 longer)) (2 necessary)) (2 things))) (2 (2 while) (2 (2 looking) (2 (2 into) (2 (2 #) (2 366))))))) (2 .)))))
Just thought, I'd share them in a separate PR, feel free to discard all of this if you where already aware of these things or if they just don't matter.
(1 (2 (2 Just) (2 thought)) (1 (3 (2 ,) (3 (3 (2 I) (3 (2 'd) (3 (3 (3 share) (2 them)) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 separate) (2 PR))))))) (2 ,))) (2 (2 (2 (2 feel) (2 (2 free) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 discard) (2 (2 all) (2 (2 of) (2 this)))) (2 (2 if) (2 you)))))) (2 (2 where) (2 (2 (2 (2 already) (2 (2 aware) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 these) (2 things))))) (2 or)) (2 (2 if) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 just) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 matter)))))))) (2 .))))
Tiny bit of background: on the way from Rails 3 to 4, they got rid of the inline-code initializer - I just remembered it was part of the upgrade guide.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 Tiny) (2 (2 bit) (2 (2 of) (2 background)))) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 on) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 way)) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 (2 (2 Rails) (2 3)) (2 to)) (2 4))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 (2 got) (2 rid)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 initializer))))))))) (2 -)) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 just) (2 (2 remembered) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 was) (2 (2 part) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 upgrade) (2 guide))))))))))) (2 .))
The Teams app already uses the new preferred way - the inline-code file, so the initializer is obsolete, all env vars are already set on Heroku.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (1 (1 (1 (2 The) (2 (2 Teams) (2 app))) (2 (2 already) (2 (2 uses) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 new) (2 (2 preferred) (2 way)))) (2 -)) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 file))))))) (2 ,)) (2 so)) (1 (2 (2 the) (2 initializer)) (1 (2 is) (2 obsolete)))) (2 ,)) (2 all)) (1 (2 (2 env) (2 vars)) (2 (2 (2 are) (2 already)) (2 (2 set) (2 (2 on) (2 Heroku)))))) (2 .))
*This means one could then also remove the inline-code from the Heroku config.
(2 (2 (2 *) (2 (2 This) (2 (2 means) (2 one)))) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 could) (2 then)) (2 also)) (2 (2 (2 remove) (2 (2 the) (2 inline-code))) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 Heroku) (2 config)))))) (2 .)))
*

Since January '15 Heroku also recommends Puma as a webserver, due to some severe problems with Unicorn.
(1 (1 (2 *) (1 (2 Since) (2 (2 January) (2 '15)))) (2 (2 (2 Heroku) (2 also)) (2 (2 (1 (1 (2 (2 recommends) (2 Puma)) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 a) (2 webserver)))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 due) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 some) (2 (2 severe) (1 problems))) (2 (2 with) (2 Unicorn)))))) (2 .))))
I just added there default Puma config, it's approx.
(2 (2 (2 I) (2 (2 just) (2 (2 added) (2 (2 there) (1 (2 default) (2 (2 Puma) (2 config))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 (2 's) (2 approx)) (2 .)))))
the same as the unicorn config before.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 same)) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 the) (2 unicorn)))) (2 (2 config) (2 before))) (2 .))
Plus: I don't see a reason why not to use it in development as well.
(2 (2 Plus) (2 (2 :) (2 (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 (2 (2 see) (2 (2 a) (2 reason))) (2 (2 (2 why) (1 not)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 use) (2 it)) (2 (2 in) (2 development))) (2 (2 as) (2 well)))))))) (2 .))))

(2 (2 (2 As) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 said) (2 ,)) (2 (2 feel) (2 (2 free) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 discard) (2 (2 these) (2 commits))))))))) (1 (2 ,) (2 (2 I) (1 (2 just) (2 (1 (2 wanted) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (1 not) (2 directly)) (2 (2 (2 forget) (2 (2 about) (2 (2 these) (2 things)))) (2 (2 when) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 saw) (2 (2 (2 (2 them) (2 :)) (2 v)) (2 :))))))))) (2 .))))))

While I'm not a native native speaker, all of my secondary school education was in an English school, so I think my level is pretty good :) I wouldn't consider “Please do this and this” as 'rude' to English speakers, it just might sound less friendly and is used more in written notices (e.g. instructions) than in the spoken, everyday language.
(3 (3 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 While) (1 (2 I) (1 (2 (2 'm) (1 not)) (1 (2 a) (1 (2 native) (2 (2 native) (2 speaker))))))) (1 (2 ,) (1 (1 (2 all) (1 (2 of) (1 (2 my) (1 (2 secondary) (2 (2 school) (2 education)))))) (2 (2 was) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 an) (2 (2 English) (2 school)))))))) (2 ,)) (2 so)) (3 (2 I) (3 (2 think) (3 (1 (2 my) (2 level)) (3 (2 is) (3 (3 (2 pretty) (3 (3 good) (3 (3 (3 (3 :-RRB-) (2 (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 would) (2 n't)) (2 consider))) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 Please) (2 (2 do) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 this) (2 and)) (2 this)) (2 '')) (2 (2 (2 as) (2 (2 `) (2 (1 (1 rude) (2 ')) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 English) (2 speakers)))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 just) (1 (2 might) (1 (2 sound) (2 (2 less) (2 friendly)))))))))))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 (2 used) (2 more)) (2 (2 in) (1 (2 (3 written) (2 notices)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 e.g.) (2 instructions)) (2 -RRB-)))))))))) (2 (2 than) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 spoken) (1 (2 ,) (2 (2 everyday) (2 language))))))))))))) (2 .))
I can definitely double-check this with a native speaker at the office tomorrow, but using “Please” at the front of a sentence is always my preferred variant, because it's more common and what people are used to.
(2 (2 (3 (3 (3 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 can) (3 definitely)) (2 (2 (2 (2 double-check) (2 this)) (1 (2 with) (2 (1 (2 a) (2 (2 native) (2 speaker))) (2 (2 at) (2 (2 the) (2 office)))))) (2 tomorrow)))) (2 ,)) (2 but)) (2 (2 (2 (2 using) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 Please) (2 '')))) (2 (2 at) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 front)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 a) (2 sentence)))))) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 is) (2 always)) (2 (2 my) (2 (2 preferred) (2 variant)))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 (2 (2 because) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 's) (2 (2 more) (2 common))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 what) (2 (2 people) (2 (2 are) (2 (2 used) (2 to))))))))) (2 .))

I think we have to differentiate two things:.
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 (2 think) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 differentiate) (2 (2 two) (2 things))))))) (2 :)) (2 .)))
- the user profile of a coach offering to help coach a team (in the same way that a coaching company would offer a space), findable through the community page
- the information of a coach attached to a team and an application

unfortunately, these things don't necessarily overlap.
(2 (2 -) (1 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 user) (2 profile))) (2 (2 of) (3 (2 (2 a) (2 coach)) (3 (3 (3 (2 offering) (3 (2 to) (3 (4 help) (3 (3 (2 coach) (3 (2 a) (3 team))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 same) (2 way))) (1 (2 that) (1 (1 (2 a) (2 (2 coaching) (2 company))) (2 (2 would) (2 (2 offer) (2 (2 a) (2 space)))))))) (2 -RRB-))))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 (2 findable) (2 (2 through) (2 (2 the) (2 (3 community) (2 page))))) (2 (2 -) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 information)) (3 (2 of) (3 (2 (2 a) (2 coach)) (3 (2 attached) (3 (2 to) (3 (2 a) (3 team))))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 (2 an) (2 application)) (2 (2 unfortunately) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (2 these) (2 things)) (2 (2 do) (2 n't))))))))))))) (2 (2 (2 necessarily) (2 overlap)) (2 .))))
Sure, a coach will have the same experience regardless, but objectively, if a coach is attached to, say, two teams we end up choosing, and that in their profile they write down “availability: 40 hours / week” I doubt they'll have 40 hours / week for both teams, if that makes sense.
(2 (3 Sure) (2 (2 ,) (1 (2 (2 a) (2 coach)) (2 (2 (2 will) (1 (2 (2 have) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 same) (2 experience))) (1 (2 regardless) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 but) (2 (2 objectively) (2 ,))))))) (1 (2 if) (1 (2 (2 a) (2 coach)) (1 (2 (2 is) (1 (2 attached) (1 (2 (2 (2 (2 to) (2 ,)) (2 say)) (2 ,)) (2 (2 two) (2 teams))))) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 we) (2 (2 (2 end) (2 up)) (2 choosing))) (2 ,)) (2 and)) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 (2 in) (2 (2 their) (2 profile))) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 (3 write) (2 down)) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 availability) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 40) (2 hours)) (2 (2 /) (2 week)))) (2 '')) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 doubt) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 'll) (2 (2 (2 (2 have) (2 (2 (2 (2 40) (2 hours)) (2 (2 /) (2 week))) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 both) (2 teams))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 if) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 makes) (2 sense))))))))))))))))))))) (2 .)))))
So, I think if we need more info from the coaches in order to rate the applications better, this needs to be done by the coaches after signing up and once they have a better idea of which teams they plan to coach.

As @carpodaster already wrote, “we removed the "hours per week" last year since it is too hard to estimate anyway and it won't save them from life that happens” — so I'd be in favour of sticking to that, and not adding the hours/week again as it's often not really a good indicator of how much time they will ultimately spend on the program helping a team.

I see some difficulties here...
1.
(2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 see) (2 (2 some) (2 difficulties))) (2 here)) (2 ...)) (2 1)) (2 .)))
From a technical perspective: it would make all existing user profiles invalid :see-no-evil_monkey:.
(1 (1 (2 From) (1 (2 a) (2 (2 technical) (2 perspective)))) (2 (2 :) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 (2 would) (2 (2 make) (2 (2 (2 (1 (2 (2 all) (2 (2 existing) (2 user))) (2 (2 profiles) (2 invalid))) (2 :)) (2 see-no-evil_monkey)) (2 :)))) (2 .)))))
I know we had something similar with the "city" or "country" field one, but I don't remember how we solved it...
2.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 I) (2 (2 know) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 had) (2 (2 something) (2 (2 (2 similar) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 city) (2 (2 '') (2 (2 or) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 country) (2 '')))))))))) (2 (2 field) (2 one)))))))) (2 ,)) (2 but)) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 do) (2 n't)) (2 (2 remember) (2 (2 how) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 solved) (2 it)))))))) (2 ...)) (2 2)) (2 .))
From a human perspective: we may eventually insult or scare off groups of people unsure about the level of their knowledge and experience by "forcing" them to come up with some technologies and languages they are experienced in...

Maybe we have to come up with "softer" approaches to get this data.
(0 (1 (2 From) (1 (2 a) (2 (2 human) (2 perspective)))) (2 (2 :) (1 (2 we) (2 (1 (2 (2 may) (2 eventually)) (1 (3 (1 insult) (2 or)) (1 (1 (1 (1 (2 scare) (1 off)) (1 (2 groups) (1 (2 of) (1 (2 people) (1 (1 unsure) (2 (2 about) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 level)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 their) (2 (2 (2 knowledge) (2 and)) (2 experience))))))))))) (2 (2 by) (2 (2 ``) (2 (1 (1 forcing) (2 '')) (2 them))))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 come) (2 up)) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 (2 some) (2 (2 (2 technologies) (2 and)) (2 languages))) (2 (2 (2 (2 they) (2 (2 are) (2 (2 experienced) (2 in)))) (2 ...)) (2 (2 Maybe) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 (2 have) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 come) (2 up)) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 softer) (2 (2 '') (2 approaches)))))))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 get) (2 (2 this) (2 data))))))))))))))) (2 .)))))
I could for instance imagine adding a reminder to fill out the profile information into the confirmation email or showing a friendly reminder when a user without a filled out profile logs in... there are several possibilities.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 could) (2 (2 for) (2 instance))) (2 (2 imagine) (2 (2 (2 (2 adding) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 reminder) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 fill) (2 out)) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 profile) (2 information)))) (2 (2 into) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 confirmation) (2 email))))))))) (2 or)) (2 (3 (2 showing) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 friendly) (2 reminder)))) (2 (2 when) (2 (2 (2 (2 a) (2 user)) (2 (2 without) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 filled)) (2 (2 out) (2 profile))))) (2 (2 logs) (2 in))))))))) (2 ...)) The inline-code has redirect_to's to an url you can define in the parameter (see why it warns about them here ).
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 There) (2 (2 are) (2 (2 (2 two) (2 things)) (2 (2 (2 marked) (2 (2 as) (2 inline-code))) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 I) (1 (2 (2 am) (1 not)) (2 (2 sure) (2 (2 (2 (2 if) (2 and)) (2 how)) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 want) (2 (2 to) (2 (3 fix) (2 them)))))))))))))) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 The) (2 inline-code)) (2 (2 has) (2 (2 (2 redirect_to) (2 's)) (2 (2 to) (3 (3 (2 (2 an) (2 url)) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 define) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 parameter))))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 see) (2 (2 why) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 (2 warns) (2 (2 about) (2 them))) (2 here))))) (2 -RRB-))))))))) (2 .))

(2 (2 (2 (2 Straightforward) (2 :)) (2 (2 (2 **) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 follow) (2 (2 the) (2 link))) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 the) (2 email)))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 get) (2 (2 their) (2 email)))) (2 confirmed))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 (1 (2 (2 (2 edit) (2 (2 their) (2 (2 profile) (2 info)))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 save) (2 changes))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 get) (2 (2 (2 their) (2 (2 coach) (2 status))) (2 (2 (2 confirmed) (2 automatically)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 we) (2 (2 (2 want) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 little) (2 clicks)))) (2 (2 (2 as) (2 possible)) (2 (2 I) (2 guess))))) (2 -RRB-)))))))))) (2 .))

* allow mentor to view a list of applications **from the current season** for their projects (they may have multiple) and a show view for each
* don't allow to view other applications - 404

* the values shown are already adapted for this year's data model.

Quick note on how I implemented the comments:.
(2 (2 Quick) (2 (2 (2 (2 note) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 how) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 implemented) (2 (2 the) (2 comments))))))) (2 :)) (2 .)))
**Notes** by mentors on applications for their projects are internally represented as inline-codes in the mentor namespace -> inline-code and use the inline-code table under the hood.
(1 (1 (0 (1 (2 (2 **) (2 Notes)) (1 (2 (2 **) (2 (2 by) (2 (2 mentors) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 applications) (2 for)))))) (1 (2 (2 their) (2 projects)) (2 (1 (2 are) (2 internally)) (2 (2 represented) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 inline-codes) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 mentor) (2 namespace))))))))))) (2 -)) (2 (2 >) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 inline-code) (2 and)) (2 use)) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 table)))) (2 (2 under) (2 (2 the) (2 hood)))))) (2 .))
It was not possible / is super difficult to just use the existing inline-code model with it's polymorphic inline-code association, since there are already comments on applications.
(3 (2 It) (3 (3 (2 (2 was) (1 not)) (3 (2 possible) (2 (2 /) (3 (4 (4 (4 (2 is) (4 (4 super) (2 difficult))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 just) (2 (2 use) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 existing) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 model)))) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 (2 it) (2 's)) (2 (2 polymorphic) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 association)))))))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 since) (2 (2 there) (2 (2 (2 are) (2 already)) (2 (2 comments) (2 (2 on) (2 applications)))))))))) (2 .)))
Including the mentor's personal notes here would cause confusion in other parts of the application plus interfere in the project proposal logic.
(2 (2 (2 Including) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 mentor) (2 's))) (2 (2 personal) (2 notes)))) (2 (2 here) (2 (2 (2 would) (2 (2 cause) (1 (2 (2 confusion) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 other) (2 parts)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 application) (3 plus))))))) (1 (2 interfere) (1 (2 in) (1 (2 the) (1 (2 project) (2 (2 proposal) (2 logic))))))))) (2 .))))
Using the exiting inline-code model is also impossible - they are only tied to a user *(and I did not want to change this)*.
(1 (1 (2 Using) (2 (1 (1 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 exiting) (2 (2 inline-code) (2 model)))) (1 (2 (2 is) (2 also)) (1 impossible))) (2 -)) (2 (2 they) (2 (2 (2 are) (2 only)) (2 (2 tied) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 user)) (2 *)))))))) (2 (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 and) (2 (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 did) (1 not)) (2 (2 want) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 change) (2 this)))))) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 (2 *) (2 .))))
So the inline-code is just a inline-code, not interfering with other comments and each mentor only has one per inline-code, using it as a kind of personal notes field that she can also empty again.
(2 (2 So) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 inline-code)) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 is) (2 just)) (2 (2 a) (2 inline-code))) (2 ,)) (2 (1 not) (2 (2 interfering) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 other) (2 comments))))))) (2 and)) (2 (2 (2 each) (2 mentor)) (2 (2 only) (2 (2 has) (2 (2 one) (2 (2 per) (2 inline-code))))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 (2 (2 using) (2 it)) (1 (2 as) (1 (2 (2 a) (3 kind)) (1 (2 of) (1 (2 personal) (2 (2 notes) (2 field))))))) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 she) (2 (2 (2 can) (2 also)) (2 (1 empty) (2 again))))))) (2 .)))

Follow up to my last comment about **missing parts** (the navigation): I cleaned up the current navigation and basically replaced it with a classic responsive bootstrap one in order to find a place to *"squeeze"* in this new item I called inline-code.
(2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 Follow) (2 up)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 my) (2 (2 last) (2 comment))) (2 (2 about) (1 (2 **) (2 (2 missing) (2 parts))))) (2 **)) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 navigation)) (2 -RRB-)))))) (2 :)) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 cleaned) (2 up)) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 current) (2 navigation)))) (2 and)) (2 (2 basically) (2 (2 (2 (2 replaced) (2 it)) (2 (2 with) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 classic) (2 (2 responsive) (2 (2 bootstrap) (2 one))))) (2 (2 in) (2 order))))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 find) (2 (2 a) (2 place))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 *) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 squeeze) (2 '')))) (2 *)))) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 (2 this) (2 (2 new) (2 item))) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 called) (2 inline-code)))))))))))) (2 .))

Quick note on why I used SQL and added a new index to a certain path in the hstore: From what I have seen in the Teams app in terms of view code (especially related to ratings), I prefer to have more complex things unit-testalbe as server-code rather then untested view helpers with global scope.
(2 (2 Quick) (2 (2 note) (2 (2 on) (2 (2 why) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 used) (2 (2 SQL) (2 (2 and) (3 (2 added) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 new) (2 (2 index) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 certain) (2 (2 path) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 hstore) (2 (2 :) (2 (2 From) (2 (2 what) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 seen) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 Teams) (2 (2 app) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 terms) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 view) (2 (2 code) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 especially) (2 (2 related) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 ratings) (2 (2 -RRB-) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 prefer) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 have) (2 (2 more) (3 (2 complex) (2 (2 things) (2 (2 unit-testalbe) (2 (2 as) (1 (2 server-code) (1 (2 rather) (1 (2 then) (1 (1 untested) (1 (2 view) (1 (2 helpers) (2 (2 with) (1 (2 global) (2 (2 scope) (2 .))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))
I could have (and also did first) written the SQL statements with AR, but they just end up far less readable with nasty Node-js like brackets and stuff.

(3 (3 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 The) (2 way)) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 have) (2 it)) (2 now)))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 may) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 huge) (2 statement)))))))) (2 ,)) (2 but)) (4 (2 it) (4 (4 (2 's) (4 (4 super) (2 (2 easy) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 read) (2 and)) (2 understand)))))) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 (2 if) (2 (2 one) (2 (2 knows) (2 (2 about) (2 hstore))))) (2 -RRB-)))))) (2 .))
By only pulling out the fields mentors should have access to, we won't have a *"security problem"* of showing them too much information about the applications they should not have access to.

@techchic quick tip: if you stay on the branch you created to make the first pull request (inline-code in your fork), you should be able to make the changes there and push — that way, you won't have to create a new PR, the changes will be added automatically to your current PR ( #668 )
Let me know if you need any help with that :)
.

Currently, when reviewing projects we only have 3 states available: “proposed”, “accepted” and “rejected”.
(2 (2 (2 (2 Currently) (2 ,)) (1 (2 when) (1 (1 (1 (1 (2 reviewing) (1 (2 projects) (2 (2 we) (1 (2 only) (2 (2 have) (1 (2 (2 3) (2 states)) (2 available))))))) (2 :)) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 proposed) (2 '')))) (2 (2 ,) (1 (2 ``) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 accepted) (2 '')) (2 and)) (2 ``)) (1 rejected)) (2 ''))))))) (2 .))
Usually reviewing projects is pretty straight forward and we can make decisions right away, but in some cases, I found myself needing to check something with the maintainers (it usually takes a couple of days) or asking for feedback from the rest of the team, and then moving on.
(3 (2 Usually) (3 (2 reviewing) (3 (2 projects) (3 (2 is) (3 (2 pretty) (3 (2 straight) (3 (2 forward) (2 (2 and) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 make) (3 (2 decisions) (2 (3 right) (2 (2 away) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 but) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 some) (2 (2 cases) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 found) (2 (2 myself) (2 (2 needing) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 check) (2 (2 something) (2 (2 with) (1 (2 the) (1 (2 maintainers) (1 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 it) (1 (2 usually) (2 (2 takes) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 couple) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 days) (2 (2 -RRB-) (2 (2 or) (2 (2 asking) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 feedback) (2 (2 from) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 rest) (2 (2 of) (3 (2 the) (3 (3 team) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 and) (2 (2 then) (2 (2 moving) (2 (2 on) (2 .)))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))
As I usually review projects in batches, I sometimes forget which projects I've commented on or am waiting for an answer from; this leads to me clicking projects I've already partly “reviewed” when I go through new applications.

The current placeholder page for inline-code shows the date and time on which applications will open.
(2 (2 (2 (2 The) (2 (2 current) (2 (2 placeholder) (2 page)))) (2 (2 for) (2 inline-code))) (2 (2 (2 shows) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 (2 date) (2 and)) (2 time))) (2 (2 (2 on) (2 which)) (2 (2 applications) (2 (2 will) (2 open)))))) (2 .)))
The system is smart enough to translate that into the user's set timezone (which can be set in the user profile by the user), but we've hardcoded “UTC” into the sentence, which leads to showing two timezones instead of just one.
(1 (2 The) (2 (2 system) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 smart) (2 (2 enough) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 translate) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 into) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 user) (2 (2 's) (2 (2 set) (2 (2 timezone) (2 (2 -LRB-) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 can) (2 (2 be) (2 (2 set) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 user) (2 (2 profile) (2 (2 by) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 user) (2 (2 -RRB-) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 but) (2 (2 we) (2 (2 've) (2 (2 hardcoded) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 UTC) (2 (2 '') (2 (2 into) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 sentence) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 leads) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 showing) (2 (2 two) (2 (2 timezones) (2 (2 instead) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 just) (2 (2 one) (2 .))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))

The best fix scenario would be to show the opening time in the user's timezone as a default, and fallback on the time value in UTC if no user timezone has been set.

(2 (2 Okay) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 (2 tried) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 reproduce) (2 it)))) (2 .)))))
My findings

* This is a 2 step system, after the user clicked on sign in, that person is redirected to
  a profile edit page where more details need to be filled out
* The system only sends a mail if the profile is filled out completely.
(1 (2 My) (1 (2 findings) (2 (2 *) (1 (2 This) (1 (2 is) (0 (2 a) (0 (2 2) (1 (2 step) (1 (2 system) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 after) (1 (2 the) (1 (2 user) (1 (2 clicked) (1 (2 on) (1 (2 sign) (1 (2 in) (1 (2 ,) (1 (2 that) (1 (2 person) (1 (2 is) (1 (2 redirected) (2 (2 to) (1 (2 a) (1 (2 profile) (2 (2 edit) (2 (2 page) (2 (2 where) (2 (2 more) (2 (2 details) (2 (2 need) (2 (2 to) (1 (2 be) (1 (2 filled) (2 (2 out) (1 (2 *) (1 (2 The) (1 (2 system) (1 (2 only) (1 (2 sends) (1 (2 a) (2 (2 mail) (2 (2 if) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 profile) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 filled) (2 (2 out) (2 (2 completely) (2 .))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))))
This is as specified in the
  ticket.
(2 (2 This) (2 (2 (2 (2 is) (2 as)) (2 (2 specified) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 the) (2 ticket))))) (2 .)))
So it is totally okay that the stuff is not mailed.
(1 (2 So) (1 (2 it) (1 (1 (1 (2 is) (2 (2 totally) (2 okay))) (2 (2 that) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 stuff)) (2 (1 (2 is) (1 not)) (2 mailed))))) (2 .))))
We only send the mail when the person
  finished registering.
(1 (2 We) (2 (2 only) (2 (2 (2 send) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 mail)) (2 (2 when) (1 (2 (2 the) (2 person)) (2 (2 finished) (2 registering)))))) (2 .))))
We might need to clearify the wording and add a banner to all pages directing 
  to the profile edit page as long as the person hasn't finished that step.
(2 (2 We) (2 (2 (2 might) (2 (2 need) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 (2 clearify) (2 (2 the) (2 wording))) (2 and)) (2 (2 (2 (3 add) (2 (2 a) (2 banner))) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 all) (2 pages)) (2 (2 directing) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 profile) (2 (2 edit) (2 page))))))))) (2 (2 (2 as) (2 long)) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 person)) (2 (2 (2 has) (2 n't)) (1 (2 finished) (2 (2 that) (2 step)))))))))))) (2 .)))
* I can't reproduce the endless loop locally but I suspect it has something to do with a profile in a wrong state.
(1 (1 (1 (1 (2 *) (1 (2 I) (2 (1 (2 ca) (2 n't)) (2 (2 (2 reproduce) (2 (2 the) (2 (2 endless) (2 loop)))) (2 locally))))) (2 but)) (2 (2 I) (2 (2 suspect) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 has) (2 (2 something) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 do) (2 (2 with) (1 (2 (2 a) (2 profile)) (1 (2 in) (1 (2 a) (1 (1 wrong) (2 state)))))))))))))) (2 .))

@bitboxer I think the problem is that some users don't get to the edit profile page at all.

This changes the navigation to a *"classic"* Bootstrap navigation as specified in #380, grouping some items and moving them into dropdowns - in order to have enough space.
(2 (2 This) (2 (2 (2 (2 changes) (1 (2 the) (1 (2 (2 navigation) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 (2 a) (2 (2 *) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 classic) (2 ''))))) (2 *)))) (2 (2 Bootstrap) (2 navigation))))) (2 (2 as) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 specified) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 #) (2 380)))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 grouping) (2 (2 some) (2 items)))) (2 and)) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 moving) (2 them)) (2 (2 into) (2 dropdowns))) (2 -)) (2 (2 (2 in) (2 order)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 have) (1 (2 enough) (2 space))))))))) (2 .)))
If you want to *"highlight*" a certain item more prominent, there'd be still enough space for it.
(2 (2 (2 If) (2 (2 you) (2 (2 want) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 *) (2 (2 (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 highlight) (2 (2 *) (2 '')))) (2 (2 a) (2 (2 certain) (2 item)))) (2 (2 more) (2 prominent)))))))) (2 (2 ,) (2 (2 there) (2 (2 (2 'd) (2 (2 be) (2 (1 (2 (2 still) (2 enough)) (2 space)) (2 (2 for) (2 it))))) (2 .)))))

(2 (2 Just) (2 (1 not) (2 (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 putting) (2 (2 **) (2 everything))) (2 (2 **) (2 (2 in) (2 (2 one) (2 line)))))) (2 .))))

This also adds an *"orga dashboard*" page, which is for now basically just an aggregation of all links relevant for organizers.
(2 (2 This) (2 (2 also) (2 (2 (2 adds) (2 (2 (2 (2 an) (2 (2 *) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 orga) (2 (2 dashboard) (2 (2 *) (2 (2 '') (2 page)))))))) (2 ,)) (2 (2 which) (2 (2 (2 is) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 (2 now) (2 basically)) (2 just)) (2 (2 (2 an) (2 aggregation)) (2 (2 of) (2 (2 all) (2 links))))))) (2 (3 relevant) (2 (2 for) (2 organizers))))))) (2 .))))
The approach for the *"sub-navigation"* there is similar to how it is done for the inline-code and inline-code space, using breadcrumbs (adapted from @michaelem :green_heart: )

See here:.
(2 (2 (2 (2 The) (2 approach)) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 *) (2 (2 ``) (2 (2 sub-navigation) (2 ''))))) (2 *)))) (2 (2 there) (2 (2 (2 (2 (2 is) (2 similar)) (2 (2 to) (2 (2 how) (2 (2 it) (2 (2 is) (2 (2 done) (2 (2 for) (2 (2 (2 (2 the) (2 (2 (2 (2 inline-code) (2 and)) (2 inline-code)) (2 space))) (2 ,)) (2 (1 (2 (2 using) (2 breadcrumbs)) (3 (2 -LRB-) (2 (3 (2 adapted) (3 (2 from) (3 (3 (2 (2 @michaelem) (2 :)) (4 green_heart)) (2 :)))) (2 -RRB-)))) (2 (2 See) (2 here))))))))))) (2 :)) (2 .))))
